description: Renault FT was the world's first modern tank design during the Great War.
However, its low speed was an obvious shortcoming, and some units revised
the design with a more powerful engine and KÃ©gresse tracks and suspension.
By 1939, even those few modernized models are hopelessly slow and unreliable.
Renault FT was the first turreted tank of the Great War, and it was
widely produced afterwards. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world, including nearly 100 in
Poland. This model is armed with a single short 37mm gun.
Renault FT was the first turreted tank of the Great War, and it was
widely produced afterwards. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world, including nearly 100 in
Poland. This model is armed only with a turret-mounted machine gun.
Polish armoured forces in 1939 are dominated by tankettes,
with around half of the TK-3 variant. Originally developed
in 1930 on the basis of the British Carden Lloyd, it is badly
outclassed by proper tanks, yet it is still widely deployed
as part of infantry and cavalry companies.
The TKS tankette is an advanced version of the TK-3 designed in
1933, with an improved hull, suspension, wider tracks and a
Polish-built Fiat engine.
The TKS tankette is an advanced version of the TK-3 designed in
1933, with an improved hull, suspension, and a Polish-built Fiat
engine. About two dozen were armed with a 20mm autocannon, allowing
them to present a genuine threat to the contemporary armoured vehicles.
A successor to Renault FT, designed as a light infantry support
tank. It's well-protected, yet slow to move and retains the outdated
weaponry of its predecessor. Poland ordered 100 units to supplement
its 7TP tanks, but only 50 were delivered in time.
Hotchkiss H39 improved upon the H35 with a more reliable and capable engine,
but it is still sluggish due to its comparatively heavy armour and very narrow tracks.
A test series of three tanks were exported to Poland in July of 1939.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
a Type A model, with twin turrets mounting a machine gun in each.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
a Type B model, with a single turret mounting a short-barreled
47mm gun.
Like the Soviet T-26, 7TP (7-tonne Polish) design was a more advanced and better armed
evolution of the British Vickers Mark E. It is, however, still lightly armoured and with
a weaker engine than many of its contemporaries. Around 160 models were available by 1939,
including the early-production models and its uparmoured variant.
This was the early dual turret version of the Polish 7TP tank.
The main differences between it and the Vickers 6-Ton Mark A
are in a more powerful and reliable engine, the installation of a
high-calibre machine gun in one of the turrets and the presence of a
radio set on commander vehicles.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
an early production model VAU-33, which would go on to become the 7TP.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
a later production model VAU-33, which would go on to become the 7TP.
9TP (9-tonne Polish) design was the up-armoured version of the 7TP design, itself based
off the British Vickers Mark E. Only a small number of models were available by the outbreak
of the Second World War.
The Taczanka was developed as a mobile machine gun. This version
has a heavy machine gun mounted on the back of a Fiat 508 truck.
These WW1-era French vehicles were the first armoured cars bought by the independent
Poland. By 1939, they were long obsolete and only used by the police force. Nevertheless
several were still deployed in an attempt to combat the German invasion.
The wz. 28 was an early Polish armoured car, inspired by the half-tracked
French armoured cars of the 1920s. The half-tracked design proved difficult
to maintain and was a poor fit with the vehicle's underpowered engine, so
the production of this design soon stopped in favour of the more conventional
wz. 34, and only were still usable in 1939. This variant is armed with a French
37mm gun.
The wz. 28 was an early Polish armoured car, inspired by the half-tracked
French armoured cars of the 1920s. This variant is armed with a 7.92mm
Hotchkiss machine gun.
The wz. 29 was one of the first Polish armoured cars. While more heavily armed
than its successors, it was too unwieldy, too prone to bogging down and presented
a high profile. About a dozen were made before production ceased, and only eight
vehicles were deployed in 1939.
The wz.34 was the standard armoured car of the Polish military. This
early model is only armed with a 7.92mm Hotchkiss machine gun. There is
a large door on the rear of the vehicle that the driver can use as a hatch.
The wz. 34 was the standard armoured car of the Polish military. This
later model is armed with a 37mm main gun. There is
a large door on the rear of the vehicle that the Driver can use as a hatch.
This was the light field support gun developed by Puteaux during WW1 to
help the troops combat machine gun nests, and later adapted for Renault
FT and the subsequent light tanks. Some of these pieces were exported to
Poland, and were used in 1939.
Designed by the Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors, this 37mm anti-tank gun
was used by many forces during the war. It is highly effective against
armoured cars and lightly-armoured tanks. They were manufactured under
license in Poland, and by 1939, 1200 pieces were in service.
Based on the Russian Putilov 76.2mm gun, this artillery piece
has been rechambered to fire 75mm French ammunition, including a
small number of armour-piercing shells.
This artillery gun was the first modern artillery piece, and provided
the model for most artillery pieces of the early twentieth century. It
saw extended use during the Great War, and thousands were still in service
at the start of the Second World War, with around 1,300 used by Poland. It
has a small stock of AP shells.
This long-barreled anti-aircraft gun was a Polish design
from Starachowice Works. While highly promising, only around
50 pieces were available at the time of the German invasion,
with many deployed at remote static emplacements.
This French-designed anti-aircraft gun was produced in several similar
variants. By September 1940 only a small number had been delivered
to Polish fighting units.
These howitzers were originally built by Skoda for the Austro-Hungarian army during
the Great War. After the break-up of the Austro-Hungarian empire, many guns were left
with the new Polish state.
Designed in France, this 105mm gun was both imported and produced under license
in Poland. Around 250 pieces were available in 1939, usually assigned to heavy
artillery batteries.
This is a modernized version of a French field gun from 1878. It is upgraded
with a new barrel, a gun shield and even a recoil system, although it is less
effective than on the purpose-built guns. In 1939, 43 were in service.
This WW1-era French heavy field howitzer was a widely used and
exported design, and some were manufactured under license as
well. Poland possessed 340 pieces in August 1939.
This super-heavy Skoda howitzer was designed in 1928, and 27 pieces were
exported to Poland in 1935.
This is the Polish designation for the 40mm anti-aircraft gun produced
by the Swedish arms manufacturer AB Bofors. Around 350 were available in
This French-designed anti-aircraft gun was produced in several similar
variants. Only around 100 units were available in Poland.
Polski Fiat was formed in 1932, when the state-owned factory in
Warsaw had signed a licensing agreement with the Italian Fiat
company. Polski Fiat 508 was mainly produced as a civilian vehicle,
but it also had this military version, significantly strengthened
to be able to go off-road.
Polski Fiat was formed in 1932, when the state-owned factory in
Warsaw had signed a licensing agreement with the Italian Fiat
company. It produced all domestic softskin military vehicles
of the independent Polish state, including this utility vehicle.
It was normally used to transport radio equipment or tow light
guns, but it could also fit a small group of soldiers.
Ursus A was the name given to a licensed version of the Italian
SPA 25. 800 models of this 2.5-ton truck were made between 1928
and 1931, before the superior Polski Fiat vehicles entered
production. Up to 300 vehicles were still in service with the Polish
military in 1939, even though it was slower and less reliable
than the other trucks they possessed.
Fiat 621 was by far the most widely produced military
truck in Polish service, and some vehicles were used to
carry an anti-aircraft machine gun.
Polski Fiat was formed in 1932, when the state-owned factory in
Warsaw had signed a licensing agreement with the Italian Fiat
company. It produced all domestic softskin military vehicles
of the independent Polish state, with this 3-ton truck being the most
important one. Over 13,000 were made and it transported soldiers, supplies,
and even light tanks around the country.
This is the older version of the Chevrolet military trucks, with
just a rear wheel drive. It was exported to nations with limited
domestic industry, where it was still used during the early years
of the war.
5500 Praga RVs were manufactured in Czechoslovakia between 1935 and 1939.
A third of these vehicles were exported abroad, some as far as Peru and Iran.
A fraction was purchased by the Polish Armed Forces.
The word taczanka ordinarily describes a type of light, leaf-spring horse carriage.
During the Russian Civil War, it was found well-suited for mounting a machine gun by
the Ukrainian anarchists, and was soon adopted by all sides of the Russian Civil War and
the Soviet-Polish War. In the 1930s, the Polish military used the same name for a motorized
successor mounted on a Fiat 508/518 body.
At the beginning of the 1930s, the Polish PZL P.11 was considered one of the
most advanced fighter designs in the world. However, by September 1939 it was
outclassed by more modern German and Soviet aircraft types. Most P.11 fighters
were armed with four 7.92mm machine guns.
The PZL.23 was the primary Polish light bomber and reconnaissance aircraft at
the outbreak of World War Two. Its lack of speed and manoeuvrability made it
very vulnerable to German and Soviet fighters. The PZL.23 was armed with
several 7.7mm machine guns and a bomb payload of up to 700 kilograms.
A civilian steam locomotive, designed to move a goods or passenger train.
It was likely pressed into service at short notice for a military purpose.
An armoured steam locomotive, designed to move an armoured train.
This armoured railroad car can transport infantry units to the battlefield.
Although it is limited to travel on rails, it is well-protected.
This armoured railroad car mounts two 75mm guns, each in a separate
turret. Although it is limited to travel on rails, it is well-protected
and well-armed.
The Panzer I was first produced in the early 1930s, and was intended to
serve as a training vehicle until heavier tanks could be produced. The A
variant was the first model, and gave useful experience in tank-building
to German industry. Most Panzers I A were converted to Panzer I B standard by 1939.
The Panzer I was first produced in the early 1930s, and was intended to
serve as a training vehicle until heavier tanks could be produced. The B
variant was slightly larger, heavier, and more powerful than the earlier
A variant, and this chassis was used for a number of different vehicles.
First designed in 1934, the autocannon-equipped Panzer II was always
intended to be a stop-gap solution until proper medium tanks could
be designed and built. Even so, it has proved to be a highly capable
light tank. This initial version entered production in 1937 and it
composed the bulk of all German tank forces during the early war.
Some Panzer II A models were later upgraded with additional
armour on the front of the turret and hull.
The Panzer II D had additional hull armour compared to the A variant.
This unit also represents the very similar E variant of the Panzer II.
Around 50 tanks of both variants were deployed in Poland and France in
1939 and 1940. All surviving tanks were later converted into Marder tank
destroyers or flame thrower tanks.
Based on the D and E variants of the Panzer II, the Flammpanzer II
was armed with two remotely controlled flame throwers mounted on
trackguards on each side. A smaller turret without the 20mm main gun
was used for this flame thrower tank variant. About 90 Flammpanzer II
tanks were deployed in Russia in 1941.
The Panzer II F represents a later version of the Panzer II with
heavier hull and turret front armour.
The Panzer II J was an experimental light tank design. Intended to be a heavy
reconnaissance vehicle, it had much thicker armour than the other Panzer II
variants. However, the improved protection significantly reduced the mobility
of the vehicle. Only about two dozen tanks of this type were ever built and
were only deployed on the Eastern Front.
The Panzer II L 'Luchs' or 'Lynx' was a major redesign of the model,
and was intended to serve in an armoured reconnaissance role.
The LT-35 was intended to equip Czechoslovakian army, but over 200 vehicles
were seized in March 1939 and it entered service as the Panzerkampfwagen
35(t). It was a balanced design for the early war, but far too unreliable
next to 38(t), and no new tanks or spare parts were produced by 1940. By
1942, all remaining tanks were exported to allies or converted to munition tractors.
The LT-38 was designed in Czechoslovakia, and after Germany occupied
the country in March 1939 it entered production as the Panzerkampfwagen
38(t). Unlike its predecessor, it was very reliable and needed little
maintenance, and its chassis was manufactured for the entire war, long
after the tank itself was relegated to supporting roles in 1942.
The model E of the 38(t) is an up-armoured variant that was deployed on
the Eastern Front.
First designed in 1934, the Panzer III was intended to be the main
battle tank of the German armoured forces. The D model was a prototype
model and only a very small number ever entered service. Its most unusual
feature is its twinned co-axial MGs.
The model F of the Panzer III was the first model to enter mass
production. Unlike the majority of gun tanks, it has two co-axial
machine guns. It was intended to serve the main battle tank of the
German armoured forces in 1939, but supplies remained limited until
1940, and by 1941, it was outnumbered by the more advanced models.
The model G of the Panzer III mounts a medium-length 5cm main gun,
and has additional front turret armour compared to the model F.
This model is similar to the late model G of the Panzer III,
but it has additional bolt-on armour plates added to the hull.
This variant of the Panzer III with a long 5cm gun was rolled
out at the end of 1941, and saw action in North Africa as well as
in Russia.
This Panzer III variant mounts a long-barrelled 5cm KwK L/60
and had additional armour compared to the H variant.
The Panzer III M had additional armour compared to the
L variant. Its hull side was reinforced with exterior
armour plates.
The N variant was a late attempt to extend the service life of the
Panzer III, armed with the same low-velocity 7.5cm gun as the
early Panzer IV and StuG variants. Its main task is to provide
infantry support.
The Panzer III M had additional armour compared to the
L variant. Its hull side was reinforced with exterior
armour plates. This rare variant replaces the main gun
with a flamethrower. 100 were built in early 1943.
Designed in mid-30s as an infantry support tank with a stronger HE shell and
a lower ground pressure than the Panzer III, the Panzer IV was eventually
upgunned to become the main battle tank of the wartime German forces. This
first production model had a weak engine, and only 35 were produced.
Designed in mid-30s as an infantry support tank with a stronger HE shell and
a lower ground pressure than the Panzer III, the Panzer IV was eventually
upgunned to become the main battle tank of the wartime German forces. Models
B and C had an upgraded engine and armour, but removed the bow machine gun
and stored less ammo. 177 were produced before the invasion of Poland.
Originally intended to be a support tank, the Panzer IV became the
main battle tank of the German forces during the war. First built in
1937, the A to F types of the tank were armed with a short gun and
designed to support infantry.
The E variant was similar to the D variant of the Panzer IV,
with the notable addition of applique armour on the hull and
turret.
The early F variant was designed with single-plate armour, heavier
than earlier variants, and required wider tracks to carry the increased
weight.
The F2 variant was the first Panzer IV variant equipped with
the long-barrelled 7.5 cm KwK 40 L/43 gun. It was a transitional
model with small production numbers and soon replaced with more
heavily armoured Panzer IV variants using the same gun.
Produced from May 1942, the G variant was produced in greater numbers
than the F2, but it was also meant to be another transitional model. In the summer of 1942,
many Panzer IV G tanks were upgraded to the H variant, which became
the main German late-war Panzer IV.
Production of the H variant of the Panzer IV began in June 1943,
and improved on the armour protection of the G, also adding Zimmerit
anti-magnetic mine paste to the vertical armour surfaces. This unit also represents
a number of Panzer IV Gs that were up-armoured and deployed in the summer
Introduced in February 1944, this was the last Panzer IV variant. The
J variant was designed to facilitate production compared to the
H variant. Because of this, the turret drive was no longer operated by
an engine and was instead moved using a hand crank. The size of the
fuel tank was increased to extend its operational range.
The Panther was introduced in 1943 to replace the Panzer III and IV, but ended
up serving alongside them, and its heavier cousin the Tiger, until the end of
the war. Although technically a medium tank, its total weight is quite high and
is compensated for by a powerful V-12 engine. This early variant has an unreliable
engine.
The Panther was introduced in 1943 to replace the Panzer III and IV, but ended
up serving alongside them, and its heavier cousin the Tiger, until the end of
the war. Although technically a medium tank, its total weight is quite high and
is compensated for by a powerful V-12 engine. The G variant was produced in the
most numbers.
An upgrade to the L3/35 developed in 1938, a limited number of
tanks were converted and saw service in 1943. The twin 8mm
machine guns have been replaced by a single 13.2mm machine gun.
Some were seized by the Germans, but they were mostly seen as
inadequate and handed back to the ISR. Germany kept some and used them on the Gothic line.
This was the German designation for the Italian P26/40 heavy tank. Most
of the about 100 tanks of this type were seized and deployed by German
forces after the Armistice of Cassibile.
This is a captured Stuart I or M3 Light Tank, redeployed in German service.
This is a captured Stuart Mk III (or M3A1 Stuart), redeployed
in German service.
This is a Crusader I tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Crusader II tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Crusader III tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Matilda II, captured and redeployed in German service,
where it is known as Infanterie-Kampfpanzer Mark II 748.
This is a Valentine II tank, captured and redeployed in German
service, where it is known as Infanterie Panzerkampfwagen Mk III 749.
This is a Valentine Mk III tank, captured and redeployed in German
service.
This was the German designation for the Italian M15/42 medium tank. After
the Armistice of Cassibile in September 1943, the Germans confiscated all
remaining tanks of this type and deployed them in Italy and on the Eastern
Front.
This is a Soviet T-26 M33 tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Soviet BT-7 tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Soviet T-60 tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This is a Soviet T-70 tank, captured and redeployed in German service.
This T-34 M40 has been captured by German forces on the Eastern Front
and redeployed in German service.
This T-34 M41 has been captured by German forces on the Eastern Front
and redeployed in German service.
This T-34 M42 has been captured by German forces on the Eastern Front
and redeployed in German service.
This T-34 M43 has been captured by German forces on the Eastern Front
and redeployed in German service.
This KV-1A has been redeployed in German service
This KV-1E has been captured and redeployed in German service.
The Panzer VIp, also known as the Porsche Tiger, was a prototype German
heavy tank. Almost all Porsche Tigers were converted into 'Elefant'
and 'Ferdinand' tank destroyers. The few unconverted Tiger Ps were attached
to these Panzerjager units as command vehicles.
The Panzer VIe, also known as the Tiger I, was developed in the wake
of the 1941 invasion of the USSR. The first tank to mount the 88mm gun,
its firepower and heavy armour were achieved at the cost of a high weight,
and an unreliable drivetrain.
The Panzer VIe, also known as the Tiger I, was developed in the wake
of the 1941 invasion of the USSR. The first tank to mount the 88mm gun,
its firepower and heavy armour were achieved at the cost of a high weight,
and an unreliable drivetrain. This represents a later version of the model,
with increased reliability.
The Panzer VIb, also known as the Royal or King Tiger, was intended to be a
successor to the Tiger I, but its thick armour and powerful main gun
were compromised by a lack of mobility and an unreliable engine.
Some S35 tanks captured from the French in 1940 were given German
markings and put into service by the Wehrmacht during Operation
Barbarossa.
This is a late-model R35, captured from the French in 1940 and
deployed by the Wehrmacht during Operation Barbarossa.
This Hotchkiss H39 tank was captured from the French in 1940,
and later put into service by the Wehrmacht during Operation Barbarossa.
Designed as a Battle Tank, able to support infantry but also engage
enemy tanks, the Char B-1 was the largest and most heavily-armoured
fighting vehicle of its day. Many B-1s captured by the Germans had
their hull guns replaced by flamethrowers. Most were used and lost
early in the Barbarossa campaign.
The StuG III is an assault gun built upon a Panzer III chassis.
Originally intended as infantry support, it has been adapted for
anti-tank combat as well.
This later model of StuG III has a slightly larger hull with more room for
radio equipment and ammo.
The F variant of the StuG III was the first to be armed with the
7.5cm StuF 40 L/43 gun.
From June 1942 the F variant of the StuG III had had additional armour
plating welded to the front.
The StuG III is an assault gun built upon a Panzer III chassis.
Originally intended as infantry support, it has been adapted for
anti-tank combat as well.
This is a late-production model of StuG III G, adding a coaxial
machine gun and a Rundumfeuer MG shield, allowing the loader to operate the top-mounted
machine gun without exposing himself.
This rare variant of the StuG III was armed with a Schwade flame
thrower instead of the 75mm main gun.
This is a StuG with a Panzer IV chassis. The production of the
StuG IV began in late 1943 to increase the total number of German
assault guns on all frontlines.
This is a late-production model StuG IV, adding a coaxial
machine gun and a Rundumfeuer MG shield, allowing the loader to operate the top-mounted
machine gun without exposing himself.
This was the German designation for the Italian Semovente da 75/18.
About 130 tank destroyers of this type were seized by the German forces
after the Armistice of Cassibile and around 50 more were produced
under German supervision.
This was the German designation for the Semovente da 75/34. Most of
these Italian tank destroyers were deployed by the Wehrmacht in Italy
and the Balkans.
This was the German designation for the Semovente da 105/25, the most
heavily armed and armoured Italian self-propelled gun in World War Two.
The German forces in Italy and some of their Italian allies kept using
it until the end of the war.
The Sturmhaubitze 42 was designed to serve the original purpose of
the StuG as an assault gun when more and more StuGs were being
used in a tank destroyer role. It uses the same chassis and armour
as the StuG III.
This is a conversion of the StuG III E, intended for infantry support. Only a
small number were ever produced.
The Sturmpanzer IV, nicknamed 'Brummbaer' (Grizzly Bear), was a rare
howitzer variant of the Panzer IV, intended to provide artillery support
from a safe distance. The howitzer superstructure was heavily armoured.
This is a late-production model of Sturmpanzer IV. It has a lighter
gun mount and a redesigned casemate to lessen strain on the front drivetrain.
The Gunner's hatch has been replaced with a ventilator for crew comfort.
A BMG has also been installed on the front of the superstructure.
The Hummel self-propelled 15cm artillery gun first saw action
during the Battle of Kursk in July 1943. After this it
was used by German armoured artillery battalions on all frontlines.
Introduced in early 1943, the Grille was a self-propelled 15cm sIG 33 mounted
on a Panzer 38(t) chassis. About 100 vehicles of the H variant were produced
between February and April 1943.
Introduced in early 1943, the Grille was a self-propelled 15cm sIG 33 mounted
on a Panzer 38(t) chassis. Almost 300 vehicles of the K variant were produced
between April 1943 and September 1944.
First deployed on the Eastern Front in the summer of 1943, the Wespe
was a self-propelled variant of the 10.5cm leFh. It served in German
armoured artillery battalions on all frontlines until the end of
the war.
The PanzerjÃ¤ger Tiger was converted from Porsche-built Tigers.
Known as the Elefant, it was designed as a tank destroyer, but
in combat often found itself in an assault gun role.
The PanzerjÃ¤ger Tiger was converted from Porsche-built Tigers.
Known as the Elefant, it was designed
as a tank destroyer, but often found itself in an assault gun role.
This is a later model fitted with a hull MG.
The Krupp Protze was extensively produced before the war as a tractor
for light anti-tank guns and anti-aircraft guns. By 1939, many
units had mounted their PaK 36 guns directly onto the flatbed.
However, it fared poorly compared to half-tracks and the more specialized
tank destroyers, and it gradually fell out of favour after the Polish Campaign.
Sd. Kfz. 10 light half-tracks were often used to tow PaK 35/36
AT guns, and some crews went further and mounted the gun in its
rear compartment. This early field modification does not even remove
the wheels and the split tail of the original gun, allowing for it to
be removed if needed, but also limiting its traverse atop the vehicle.
The 8.8cm FlaK 18 and its variants were found effective
as an anti-tank weapon. In 1939 the gun was mounted on
Sd.Kfz. 8 and 9 half-tracked transporters. They were used
in small numbers during the invasion of Poland, France and
on the southern sector of the Eastern Front.
Built upon a Panzer II chassis, the Marder was developed as a
makeshift tank destroyer, initially for countering Soviet tanks.
This variant has light armour but a powerful 75mm main gun.
Built upon a Panzer 38(t) chassis, the Marder was developed as a
makeshift tank destroyer, initially for countering Soviet tanks.
This early variant was equipped with a captured 76.2mm Soviet gun.
It was deployed on the Eastern Front and in North Africa.
Built upon a Panzer 38(t) chassis, the Marder was developed as a
makeshift tank destroyer, initially for countering Soviet tanks.
This later variant is equipped with a German PaK 40 gun.
Built upon a Panzer 38(t) chassis, the Marder was developed as a
makeshift tank destroyer, initially for countering Soviet tanks.
This variant has light armour but a powerful 75mm main gun.
Built upon a Panzer I chassis, this self-propelled AT gun mounts
a 4.7cm anti-tank gun.
Intended as a replacement for the StuG, the JgdPz IV is a Tank
Destroyer developed in late 1943. It is built upon a modified Panzer IV chassis.
This early production model uses thinner plates and possesses both MG apertures.
This main production model uses thicker frontal plates as well as doing away with the muzzle brake.
Additionally, MG port on the gunner's side is welded over with an armoured cap.
Built upon a Panzer 38(t) chassis, this Tank Destroyer, commonly
known as the Hetzer, was intended to replace the ad-hoc Tank
Destroyers of earlier years.
This is a Jagdpanzer IV armed with the 7.5cm PaK 42 L/70 gun used
by the Panther tank. The result was a powerful but front-heavy tank
destroyer. It was the most produced variant of this vehicle.
This is the 'A' variant of the Jagdpanzer IV/70, a tank destroyer armed
with a 7.5cm PaK 42 L/70 gun. This variant was an attempt to fit the gun
into unmodified Panzer IV hull, and was only produced in small numbers.
The Nashorn tank destroyer was armed with a powerful 88mm gun,
but its light armour made it very vulnerable to enemy fire. Most
Nashorns were used to hunt down Soviet tanks. A few were deployed
in Italy and Western Europe.
This German tank destroyer combines the chassis of the
Panzer V (Panther) with the 88mm gun of the King Tiger.
The Jagdtiger was the most heavily armoured tank ever used by
the Wehrmacht and the only German vehicle equipped with the
12.8 cm PaK 44 L/55. Because of its excessive weight of
more than 70 tonnes, it often suffered from severe technical
issues.
A vehicle born out of the experience of Battle of Stalingrad and the
desperate need for heavy fire support in a brutal urban environment.
The 380mm main gun launches rocket-assisted projectiles designed to
destroy fortifications.
Only 18 vehicles were produced, using rebuilt Tiger I chassis.
This halftrack armoured transport has been fitted with a PaK 36
anti-tank gun.
This is an SPW 251 halftrack transport fitted with a PaK 40
anti-tank gun, turning it into a dangerous tank destroyer.
This SU-85 tank destroyer has been captured by German forces on
the Eastern Front, and redeployed in German service.
The Kfz 13 was converted from an Adler touring car in 1935. Although
lightly armoured, the vehicle is completely open on its top. These
vehicles were deployed early during the war, but were pulled from
front-line combat by the end of 1941.
The Sd.Kfz.221 was designed in secret as an all-terrain armoured
car, to replace the more limited Kfz.13. 339 vehicles were produced
between 1935 and 1940. Although it is a mobile and capable scout, it
lacks a radio and its off-road capabilities are fairly limited. Moreover,
it was practically helpless against the other armoured vehicles, which
led to a series of field modifications.
This autocannon-equipped light reconnaissance vehicle was much more capable than its
predecessor, although due to a greater weight, it didn't handle as well. Over a thousand
of these armoured cars were produced, most in the first three years. They performed
well in Europe and North Africa, but were steadily displaced by half-tracks on the Eastern Front.
The Sd.Kfz. 231 was designed in the early 1930s around a civilian
truck chassis. It proved excellent on dry ground but lacked true
off-road capability and its production ended in 1937 after the
4-axle version was successfully introduced. The 140 units built
by that point continued to be used for reconnaisance until 1942.
The poor off-road performance of the 6-wheeled Sd.Kfz. 231
prompted the development of this model, which placed the engine
at the rear and gave the driver better visibility. While less
numerous than the 6-wheeled variant during the early war, its
production picked up after the invasion of the USSR, with around
450 built between July 1941 and October 1943.
This was a support variant of the PSW 231 (8 rad), armed with a
fixed short-barreled 75mm gun.
The Puma was a development of the earlier PSW 231 (8 rad) design,
with improved armour and a more powerful engine.
PanzerspÃ¤hwagen P204 was the German designation for redeployed captured
French Panhard P-178 armoured cars, also known as the AMD 35.
This halftrack has the turret from a PSW 222 or PSW 234/1
armoured car mounted on the back. Although not technically an
Armoured Car, it was used in a similar role.
This halftrack is armed with a 37mm gun and usually heads a platoon of
SPW 250/9 vehicles as armoured reconnaissance. Although not technically an
Armoured Car, it was used in a similar role.
This was first self-propelled anti-aircraft gun in German service. The
standard half-track prime mover was modified with fold-down side and rear panels
and mounted a FlaK 30 AA gun. 370 were deployed in Poland,
and over 1000 were ready for the Battle of France. In total, around 2000 were
produced by March 1942, and they were never fully
displaced by more advanced models.
The Flakpanzer 38(t) was a self-propelled anti-aircraft gun
mounted on a Panzer 38(t) chassis. By the time this AA tank
was introduced in April 1944, its single 2cm Flak 38 was no
longer considered effective enough to shoot down Allied planes.
Because of this, only a small number was built.
The Flakpanzer IV Wirbelwind was a self-propelled 2cm Flakvierling 38
anti-aircraft gun mounted on a Panzer IV chassis. Despite its low
production number, it was a fairly successful AA tank.
The Flakpanzer IV Mobelwagen was a self-propelled 3.7cm Flak 43
anti-aircraft gun mounted on a Panzer IV chassis.
First developed in the early 1930s, this was the main anti-tank gun
of German forces up to the middle of the war. From March 1943 some were
equipped with the Stielgranate 41 HEAT round, which attached to the muzzle
of the gun.
First produced in 1939, this new anti-tank gun was based on the experience
of the Spanish Civil War.
This was a stop-gap solution to the need for heavier anti-tank firepower
on the Eastern Front. A French 75 mm gun is mounted on the carriage of
a PaK 38.
The 7.62cm PaK 36r was adapted from captured Soviet 76.2mm field guns.
This anti-tank gun was developed in the wake of experiences with
heavier Russian tanks, and first deployed in 1942. It remained the
standard German anti-tank gun until the end of the war.
This 8.8cm gun was designed and manufactured by Krupp,
and has an exceptionally high armour penetration capacity.
Production of the PaK 43 failed to meet demand, so the PaK 43/41
was developed by mounting a modified PaK 43 barrel onto a carriage
assembled from other gun models. Although larger, it's just as effective
as the stock PaK 43.
The 'Puppchen' is a two-man reusable anti-tank rocket launcher,
intended to give infantry units better anti-armour capability. It
uses the same explosive charge as the smaller Panzerschreck.
This was the standard German light anti-aircraft gun of the war.
This medium-calibre AA gun was the German equivalent to the Bofors
AA gun, and during the early war it was used in both anti-air and
ground support role. Around 20,000 were produced, with some exported
to the allied nations.
This AA gun was newly designed during the war in order to be lighter and
easier to produce. It was first deployed in August 1944.
Initially designed as a heavy anti-aircraft gun, the '88'
was quicky pressed into service as an anti-tank gun, a role
in which it excelled.
This light howitzer, intended as an infantry support gun, was first
designed in the late 1920s. The mountain version of this gun was the 7.5cm GebK15.
This was the standard heavy howitzer for German forces.
This was the largest-calibre infantry gun used during the war. It
has a powerful HE shell, but is very heavy and difficult to
transport.
One of a few recoiless rifles deployed during the war, the 7.5 cm LeichtgeschÃ¼tz 40
was intended for use by units who needed to move at speed, such as paratroopers and
mountain troops.
This was the standard light howitzer for German forces.
Intended for long-range indirect fire, these were some of the
longest guns commonly in use in German artillery batteries.
Originally intended to provide smoke and gas fire support, the Nebelwerfer
is a six-barrelled rocket launcher mounted on a gun carriage adapted from
that used on the PaK 36.
This was the first German light anti-aircraft gun developed after the Great
War. Several thousand were produced, but it was steadily displaced by the
more advanced FlaK 38 during wartime.
This is a German half-track vehicle armed with a 2cm
Flakvierling 38 anti-aircraft gun. It was the most common
German self-propelled AA gun in World War 2.
This halftrack is designed to transport mechanized infantry units.
This halftrack is armed with an 80mm mortar for infantry support.
This halftrack is armed with the same low-velocity gun as the early Panzer IV.
It is intended to serve as infantry support.
This halftrack was one of the first armoured personnel carriers in
the world. Though open-top, it still offered good protection versus small
arms fire and allowed mechanized infantry divisions to overwhelm the territory
already struck by bombers and tanks before the defenders could regroup. Over 15,000
were produced throughout the war.
This armoured halftrack carries an 81mm mortar and its crew, and
is designed for close infantry support.
This halftrack is armed with the same low-velocity gun as the early Panzer IV.
It is intended to serve as infantry support.
This halftrack mounts a rotatable multiple rocket launcher. Although intended
for long-range artillery support, they sometimes find themselves on the front lines of
fighting.
First deployed in the Spring of 1944, the Panzerschreck is a rocket-
powered anti-tank shaped charge weapon. Although limited to an effective
range of about 150m., it can penetrate very thick armour and causes
heavy damage to occupants of armoured vehicles.
The Volkswagen Type 82 'Kubelwagen' was a popular command car and often
transported German officers throughout the war.
The Tempo Vidal G1200 was designed in 1937 as a light scout/command car. Its
dual-engine, all-wheel drive construction with a spare set of wheels
provided excellent off-road mobility, but it was also expensive and
few were made compared to the Kubelwagen. Many of these vehicles were
exported to allies, and the rest were mostly sent to the Eastern Front.
This was one of the main trucks used by the Wehrmacht. Widespread
during the early war, it was found inferior to the Opel Blitz, yet
its production continued until the Bremen-Sebaldsbrudk plant was
destroyed by a bombing raid in 1944. 30,000 units were built in total.
In the mid-1930s, the Wehrmacht aimed to field standardized, 6-wheeled,
full-wheel drive military trucks which could be produced in multiple
size classes. The Einheitsdiesel was
costlier than other trucks, and Germany could not afford
to both supply trucks with diesel and tanks with petrol, so
production ended in 1940. Remaining units served on the Eastern Front
While this design dates back to 1928, thousands of these trucks were
still produced between 1934 and 1942. It was deployed in Poland,
France and in the Soviet Union before getting displaced by the more
modern trucks. Their last deployment in a combat operation was in Italy in 1943.
This was the larger version of the Horch 901 staff car, used primarily to transport small
teams around the battlefield. It was also at times used to tow light anti-tank guns and
anti-aircraft guns. In total, around 8000 were produced between 1937 and 1942.
The Blitz truck, produced by the General Motors subsidiary
company Opel, provides the motorized transport backbone for
the German army. The 3-ton variant is the most common variant
in use. It is the fastest wartime truck in its payload category.
This 4.5-ton truck is the workhorse of the German armed forces.
It combines a reliable diesel engine with good performance on rough terrain.
This was one of the main truck models used by the Wehrmacht.
Around 30,000 units were built. It was slower than the Opel Blitz,
yet it was more reliable on rough terrain, and was favoured
by the Afrika Korps.
This was the Wehrmacht designation for Horch 901, which was the second most-widely produced
German staff car after the Kubelwagen. While slower, it was much more comfortable and could
carry more people and larger payloads. Nearly 20,000 were produced between 1936 and 1943,
at which point its production was assessed as too resource-intensive for the role it played.
The Henschel Hs 123 was a biplane dive bomber and close-support aircraft,
first deployed during the Spanish Civil War. Although it was outdated compared
to later single-winged aircraft, it proved to be robust and reliable, and saw
action up to 1944. This represents the A variant of the aircraft.
The Junkers Ju 87 was first deployed in the Spanish Civil War in 1937,
and continued to be used until 1945. Its distinctive inverted gull wings
and dive sirens make it one of the most recognisable dive bombers of the war.
This later version of the Ju 87 has a higher bomb load and improved MGs.
This variant was designed for attacking tanks on the Eastern Front,
and was converted from the more common D model. Two 37mm FlaK 18 guns were hung
from the wings, just outside the landing gear.
The Henschel Hs 129 was a ground-attack aircraft used in Tunisia and
on the Eastern Front. This represents the B-2 variant of the Hs 129,
the most widely used.
Designed as a fighter, the Messerschmitt Bf 109 was one of two designs
that formed the core of the Luftwaffe. This represents the E-4 or the later E-7
variant of the Bf 109, intended for ground attack.
Designed as a fighter, the Messerschmitt Bf 109 was one of two designs
that formed the core of the Luftwaffe. This represents a Bf 109 fighter
variant which is equipped with 7.62mm machine guns and 20mm cannons but
does not carry any bombs.
Designed as a twin-engine energy fighter, the Messerschmitt Bf 110 was used throughout
the entire Second World War. This unit represents a Bf 110 fighter variant with several
20mm cannons and 7.62mm machine guns.
Designed as a twin-engine energy fighter, the Messerschmitt Bf 110 was used throughout
the entire Second World War. This unit represents a Bf 110 fighter-bomber variant which
carries two 500 kg bombs in addition to its 20mm cannons and 7.62mm machine guns.
The Focke-Wulf Fw 190 fighter aircraft was one of two designs
that formed the core of the Luftwaffe. This represents the F-8
variant of the Fw 190, designed for ground-attack.
The Focke-Wulf Fw 190 fighter aircraft was one of two designs
that formed the core of the Luftwaffe. This represents a dedicated
fighter variant of the Fw 190 without any bomb payload.
The Messerschmitt Me 262 was the first mass-produced jet-powered
fighter aircraft in the world. During the last months of World War 2
in Europe, the Germans used it to fight Allied bombers and ground
forces. This unit represents a dedicated fighter variant, armed with
four 30mm MK 108 cannons.
The Messerschmitt Me 262 was the first mass-produced jet-powered
fighter aircraft in the world. During the last months of World War 2
in Europe, the Germans used it to fight Allied bombers and ground
forces. The A-2a variant was a dedicated fighter-bomber, armed with
two 30mm MK 108 cannons, up to 24 R4M rockets and a bomb payload of
up to 1000 kilograms.
The Bystrochodnij Tank (Russian for 'fast tank') was developed at the
beginning of the 1930s. It was one of the first tank designs which made
use of the Christie suspension and one of the fastest tanks of its time.
Unlike the later BT-5 and BT-7, the BT-2 was armed with a 37mm gun.
The BT-5 tank was designed to move quickly, in order to exploit
holes in enemy defensive lines.
The BT-7 tank was based on the design of the BT-5, with better turret side
armour, and a new engine and drive train.
The BT-7A artillery tank was intended to provide support for platoons
of BT fast tanks.
The T-26 tank was developed based on the British Vickers 6-ton
design, and is by far the most numerous tank in Soviet forces.
The T-26 tank was developed based on the British Vickers 6-ton
design, and is by far the most numerous tank in Soviet forces.
The OT-130 was based on the 1933 variant. The 45mm gun was replaced
with a flame thrower.
The T-26 tank was developed based on the British Vickers 6-ton
design, and is by far the most numerous tank in Soviet forces of the early war.
The models of 1937 and 1939 have improved frontal armour compared to
the original design.
The T-26 tank was developed based on the British Vickers 6-ton
design, and is by far the most numerous tank in Soviet forces.
The OT-133 was based on the 1939 variant. The 45mm gun was replaced
with a flame thrower.
Developed in the early 1930s, the T-37A amphibious tankette
was deployed by the Red Army during the invasion of Poland,
the Winter War and the first months of the German attack on
the Soviet Union. It served both as a recon and infantry
support vehicle.
First produced in 1937, the T-38 amphibious tankette was a
moderate improvement over the T-37A. Its transmission and
drivetrain were more reliable and its wider but lower profile
resulted in improved buoyancy. The T-38 was deployed in the
Winter War and during the first months of the German invasion
of the Soviet Union.
Developed from the T-37A and T-38, the T-40 tankette was armed
with a powerful 12.7mm DShK machine gun in addition to the 7.62mm
DT machine gun of earlier models. Only a few hundred were ever
produced, however, and almost all of them were destroyed
during Operation Barbarossa in 1941.
Originally intended to replace the T-26 series,
the T-50 was equipped with a three-man turret featuring a
commander cupola for improved visibility after buttoning up.
Its armour was excellent for a light tank. However, the T-50
was more costly than the T-34, and only 63 were ever produced.
Originally intended to replace the T-26 series,
the T-50 was equipped with a three-man turret featuring a
commander cupola for improved visibility after buttoning up.
Its armour was excellent for a light tank. However, the T-50
was more costly than the T-34, and only 63 were produced. This
is a later version with additional armour.
Designed for reconnaisance, the T-60 was often pressed into an
infantry support role during the early war. Its light armour protection
led to it being dubbed 'A brother's grave for two.'
Designed for reconnaisance, the T-60 was often pressed into an
infantry support role during the early war. This later model has
increased armour.
Developed in the latter part of 1941, the T-70 was another attempt
to balance firepower, speed, and armour in a light tank. Its role was
gradually overtaken by the T-34.
This is a Panzer 38(t) E which has been captured by the Red Army,
and redeployed in Soviet service.
M31 was the Soviet designation for lend-lease M3A1 Stuart light tanks,
supplied by America.
The T-28 was the first of a series of 'land battleship' tanks,
intended as an infantry support tank and to break through enemy
defenses.
The T-28 was the first of a series of 'land battleship' tanks,
intended as an infantry support tank and to break through enemy
defenses. This up-armoured version was intended to better resist
incoming anti-tank gun fire, and has an upgraded main gun.
The T-34 was the most advanced tank of the early war, and its combination
of a 76mm gun and heavy armour made it a formidable foe. It does, however,
retain the two-man turret of early tanks, and is prone to breaking down.
This is the first production model of the T-34.
This variant of the T-34 with a long-barelled gun was initially intended
for commanders, but it soon replaced the earlier model in production.
This rare variant of the T-34 was armed with a ZiS-4 57mm high-velocity
anti-tank gun. Its main purpose was to destroy enemy tanks. Only a few
were produced in late 1941, and then again in early 1943.
The Model 1942 variant of the T-34-76 received additional turret armour and
a number of minor improvements which increased its reliability.
The Model 1943 variant of the T-34-76 (already introduced in 1942)
received a redesigned turret. The Germans referred to it as the
'Mickey Mouse' turret because of its twin hatch design. This early
variant of the T-34 Model 1943 does not have a radio or commander
vision cupola.
The Model 1943 variant of the T-34-76 (already introduced in 1942)
received a redesigned turret. The Germans referred to it as the
'Mickey Mouse' turret because of its twin hatch design. This late
variant of the T-34 Model 1943 is equipped with a radio and a
commander vision cupola.
Introduced in 1944, this T-34 variant was equipped with a cast three-man
turret mounting the 85mm D-5T (later ZiS-S-53) gun. These improvements
made the T-34-85 easier to operate than its predecessors and gave it
additional turret armour and firepower. In this early variant of the
T-34-85 a hand-crank system is used to traverse the turret.
Introduced in 1944, this T-34 variant was equipped with a cast three-man
turret mounting the 85mm D-5T (later ZiS-S-53) gun. These improvements
made the T-34-85 easier to operate than its predecessors and gave it
additional turret armour and firepower. This late variant of the T-34-85
uses an electrically powered turret traverse motor.
The OT-34 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34. The 1941 variant
was armed with an ATO-41 flame thrower which replaced the hull
machine gun.
The OT-34 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34. The 1942 variant
was armed with an ATO-42 flame thrower with improved range and
additional fuel. The flame thrower replaced the hull machine gun.
The OT-34 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34. The 1943 variant
was armed with an ATO-43 flame thrower with improved range and
additional fuel compared to the ATO-41. The flame thrower replaced
the hull machine gun. This early variant of the T-34 Model 1943 does
not have a radio or commander vision cupola yet.
The OT-34 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34. The 1943 variant
was armed with an ATO-43 flame thrower with improved range and
additional fuel compared to the ATO-41. The flame thrower replaced
the hull machine gun. Unlike the early variant of the T-34 M43, this
tank is equipped with a radio and commander vision cupola.
The OT-34-85 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34-85. An ATO-43
flame thrower replaced the hull machine gun. In this early variant
of the T-34-85 a hand-crank system is used to traverse the turret.
The OT-34-85 was a flame thrower variant of the T-34-85. An ATO-43
flame thrower replaced the hull machine gun. This late variant uses
an electrically powered turret traverse motor.
This was the Soviet designation for lend-lease M3 Lee tanks.
This was the Soviet designation for lend-lease M4A2 medium tanks. Some
2000 with the 75mm gun were supplied to the Soviet Union during the
course of the war.
This was the Soviet designation for lend-lease M4A2(76)W Sherman tanks.
They were shipped to the Soviet Union starting in May 1944 and were the
only lend-lease Sherman variant with a three-inch main gun, wet stowage,
and a gyrostabilizer.
The T-III was the Russian designation for captured Panzer III J tanks.
The T-IV was the Russian designation for captured Panzer IV F1
tanks.
The T-V was the Russian designation for captured Panzer V
'Panther' tanks of the early A variant.
One of the last 'Land Battleship' tanks, the T-35 looked very impressive
but was difficult to command, prone to breakdown, and only lightly armoured.
The KV-1, known as the 'Russian Colossus' to German forces, was
intended to replace the T-35 as the main heavy tank of Soviet
forces. This represents the first production model.
Anticipating improved German guns, the KV-1E was produced as an
uparmoured variant of the heavy tank in early 1941.
This is a later variant of the KV-1 heavy tank, with improved armour
and a long-barrelled main gun.
The KV-1S was an attempt to increase the mobility and speed of the heavy
tank. Although the three-man turret was more effective, the loss of armour
protection turned it into more of a slow medium tank than a true heavy tank.
Designed to destroy fortifications, the KV-2 is unusual in that
it mounts its heavy gun in a very large and very distinctive rotatable
turret.
This was a stopgap model that combined the turret from the prototype IS-1
with the hull of the KV-1S. Only 130 were ever produced.
Developed as an answer to the German Tiger and Panther, the Iosef
Stalin 1, or IS-1 (also called IS-85) received additional armour
compared to the KV-1 as well as the new D-5T 85mm gun, which soon was
considered too weak for a heavy tank. One of the 7.62mm machine guns
was placed in the turret rear.
The Iosef Stalin 2, or IS-2 (also called IS-122) gradually replaced
the IS-1 (or IS-85) over the course of 1944. It was armed with the
D-25T 122mm gun, which offered impressive firepower but was difficult
to reload and limited the ammunition capacity of the tank stores to
only 28 shells. One of the 7.62mm machine guns was placed in the
turret rear.
The Iosef Stalin 2, or IS-2 (also called IS-122) gradually replaced
the IS-1 (or IS-85) over the course of 1944. It was armed with the
D-25T 122mm gun, which offered impressive firepower but was difficult
to reload and limited the ammunition capacity of the tank stores to
only 28 shells. This late variant was equipped with an additional
12.7mm MG and had additional armour.
This was the Soviet designation for the Matilda II, supplied through
a Lend-Lease agreement with the United Kingdom. Although it was in
many ways inferior to Soviet tanks, its presence on the Eastern Front
was welcomed after losses sustained in the Summer of 1941.
This was the Soviet designation for the Matilda II CS, supplied through
a Lend-Lease agreement with the United Kingdom. Only a small number
of this variant were deployed on the Eastern Front.
This was the Soviet designation for the Valentine II, supplied through
a Lend-Lease agreement with the United Kingdom. Most British-built tanks
sent to the Soviet Union were of this type.
This was the Soviet designation for the Valentine tank, supplied through
a Lend-Lease agreement with the United Kingdom. This late variant of the
Valentine is equipped with an OQF 6-pounder main gun.
Mark IV was the Soviet designation for the lend-lease Churchill III.
Only 301 were shipped and deployed during the war.
The T-VI was the Russian designation for captured Tiger I tanks,
redeployed into Soviet service.
The ZiS-30 was an improvised tank destroyer based on the Komsomolets armoured
artillery tractor. About 100 of them were produced and deployed in response
to the German invasion of the Soviet Union. Its 57mm ZiS-2 gun turned out to be
very effective against German armour. However, it was mounted on an unreliable
and poorly-armoured vehicle, and the crew is exposed to enemy fire.
Armed with an American version of the British OQF 6-pounder anti-tank
gun, the SU-57 was the Soviet designation for the T48 Gun Motor
Carriage, which was originally designed for the North African theatre
but arrived too late to participate in the Tunisian campaign. It was
instead provided to the Soviet Union as a lend-lease vehicle and
deployed on the Eastern Front beginning in late 1943.
The SU-75 was the Russian designation for captured StuG III
assault guns of the F and G variants.
The SU-85 was designed to destroy the latest German tanks in 1943,
and featured an 85mm anti-aircraft gun mounted on to an SU-122.
Introduced in late 1944, this variant of the SU-85 tank destroyer
received a different gun mantlet with improved armour and a new
commander vision cupola.
By the end of 1944, 85mm guns were no longer considered powerful
enough for Soviet tank destroyers. Because of this, the SU-100
was introduced in 1945. It was armed with the new D-10S 100mm gun
and equipped with a commander vision cupola.
This heavy armoured car is armed with a 45mm gun.
The BA-10 was an improved version of the BA-6, with slightly better
armour and a more powerful engine.
This armoured car was designed upon a Ford model A chassis and uses
a modified Model T engine.
This armoured car was designed upon the GAZ 4x4 automobile.
The SU-12 was the first self-propelled gun developed in the
Soviet Union. A 76mm gun is fixed to a turret on the back of a
standard truck.
Built upon a modified T-70 hull, the SU-76M was intended to serve as
a combination assault gun and tank destroyer. It soon found itself
forced into an anti-infantry support role, however, as the strength of
German armour increased. Its nickname of 'suchka' or 'bitch' reflects
the poor experience of crewmen in this vehicle.
These were built on the hull of a captured Panzer III or StuG III,
with a superstructure added housing a 76mm gun. Around 190 were built.
Development for the SU-122 began by taking captured Panzer III or StuG III hulls,
and adding a superstructure housing a 76mm gun. Later a new chassis based on
that of the T-34 was designed. Around 190 were built.
Adapted from the KV-1S, the SU-152 was originally intended to serve
as a heavy assault gun, but often found itself in an anti-tank role.
Over 700 were built.
Adapted from the KV-1S, the SU-152 was originally intended to serve
as a heavy assault gun, but often found itself in an anti-tank role.
Over 700 were built. This is a later model with a field-installed
DShK 12.7mm AAMG.
Developed from the SU-122 assault gun, the ISU-122 was armed with
the long-barrelled A-19S 122mm gun and received additional armour.
It was both used in a tank destroyer and assault gun role.
This late variant of the ISU-122 was upgraded with a semi-automatic
breech block to increase its rate of fire. The new gun mantlet was
slightly more resistant to armour-piercing shells and a 12.7mm
anti-aircraft machine gun was often added as secondary armament.
The ISU-152 was an improved version of the SU-152 assault gun.
It had additional armour and was often equipped with a 12.7mm
anti-aircraft machine gun.
The Katyusha multiple rocket launcher has a rotatable set of rails
for launching rockets at distant targets. These were built in several
configurations and on different types of chassis, including the ZIS-6
and lend-lease Studebaker trucks.
The Universal Carrier was developed in 1940 as a small, light, but
armoured transport for small teams armed with support weapons. It was also supplied
to the USSR through the lend-lease programme. This Soviet variant has a Russian
machine gun mounted in the bow.
This variant of the Universal Carrier is armed with a 2-inch mortar in the rear
compartment. One was usually asigned to every Scout and Mechanized platoon to provide
fire support.
This American half-track is armed with a machine gun in the passenger
compartment. Starting in 1943, several hundred vehicles of this type
were delivered to the USSR and UK through the lend-lease programme.
This is a quad MG mounted on the back of a GAZ truck, and was the standard Soviet
anti-aircraft vehicle of the war.
A small number of ZIS-5 trucks were outfitted with 25mm M1940
anti-aircraft guns.
The M17 Multiple Gun Motor Carriage was an M5 half-track armed
with a quad anti-aircraft machine gun. Production started in
December 1943 and about 1,000 vehicles of this type were delivered
to the USSR through the lend-lease programme before the end of
World War Two.
First produced in the USSR in the early 1930s, this was one of the most
powerful anti-tank guns of the early war.
This is an improved version of the 45mm obr. 1932, with a longer
barrel.
First developed and used in small numbers in 1941, this gun was
modified and re-deployed in 1943. Sometimes referred to as the ZIS-2.
An infantry support gun developed in 1927, this gun was later replaced
but continued in service throughout the war.
Intended as a dual-purpose field and anti-aircraft gun, this model
was introduced in 1936. It proved to be an excellent anti-tank gun.
Designed to replace the obr. 36 gun, this gun was intended for dual
use as an artillery piece and as an anti-tank gun.
This was an updated version of the 76.2mm obr. 39 field gun, with a new
carriage and muzzle brake.
This gun dates to the beginning of the century, but by the outbreak
of the war in 1939, it has been relegated to limited use.
Designed to be able to penetrate the front armour of any German tank,
the BS-3 100mm anti-tank gun was introduced in 1945 and remained in
service into the 1950s. It was also used as a field gun.
Originally imported from France by the Russian Empire, these guns
were modernized in 1930.
Originally built in France as the Schneider 10S, these guns were
imported by the Russian Empire, then modernized in 1930.
The standard medium artillery gun of first-line divisions
in the Soviet army. A version was also used in the SU-122 assault gun.
This field gun was developed in the 1930s. A slightly improved
variant was adopted in 1939 but was also referred to as the A-19,
and this unit represents both variants. It was primarily used for
indirect fire on enemy positions, but was also supplied with AP
ammo, and proved highly effective against heavy tanks.
This heavy howitzer was also intended for a anti-tank role. A version
of this gun was used on the KV-2 heavy tank.
A heavy gun that was also designed as an anti-tank gun, the 152mm
howitzer-gun continued to be used long after the war.
One of the standard light anti-aircraft guns in Soviet service, derived from
a design by Bofors.
This was the standard heavy anti-aircraft gun in Soviet service in the 1930s and early 1940s.
This heavy anti-aircraft gun was intended to replace the earlier 76.2mm AA gun.
This light all-wheel drive offroad-capable vehicle was developed in 1941 as an
alternative to GAZ-61 as a staff car, but from 1942 onwards, it was primarily used
as a basis for BA-64 armoured car. Out of nearly 700 vehicles produced in 1941 and
early 1942, virtually all were instead used as light gun tractors, justifying its
'Goat' nickname.
Introduced in late 1943 and derived from the Willys MB, the GAZ 67 was a
popular general-purpose four-wheel-drive military vehicle. By the end of
World War Two, it had become the Russian equivalent of the Jeep.
This 4.5-ton truck is the workhorse of the Soviet armed forces.
These trucks have been supplied to the USSR by America through the lend-
lease programme.
The Polikarpov I-16 fighter plane, often nicknamed 'Ishak' ('Donkey') by its
pilots, was introduced in the 1930s and formed the backbone of the Soviet Air
Force at the beginning of World War 2. It also participated in the Spanish
Civil War, the Second Sino-Japanese War, the Battle of Khalkhin Gol and the
Winter War.
The Polikarpov I-153 was a biplane designed in the late 1930s. Although
already outdated, it was one of the main Soviet fighters of the early
part of the war.
The Mikojan-Gurewitsch MiG-3 fighter planes represented a significant part of
the Soviet Air Force when the Germans invaded in the summer of 1941.
It did not fare well against the Bf 109 because it was designed
for high-altitude combat, while most dogfights occured at lower altitudes. In
early 1942, it was withdrawn from frontline service and exclusively
used for high-altitude bomber interception.
Introduced in late 1939, the Sukhoi Su-2 reconnaissance and light bomber
aircraft saw first action during the German invasion of the Soviet Union.
It was outclassed by German aircraft and withdrawn from frontline service
in early 1942.
The Ilyushin Il-2 was designed as a heavily-armoured, ground-attack
aircraft. This represents the first production, single-seat variant.
The Ilyushin Il-2 was designed as a heavily-armoured, ground-attack
aircraft. This updated model was produced from 1943 and included a rear gunner
as well as an improved engine.
The Ilyushin Il-2 was designed as a heavily-armoured, ground-attack
aircraft. The 3M variant was a dedicated tank hunter, armed with
two 37mm Nudelman-Suranov NS-37 cannons instead of the default 20mm
or 23mm cannons. However, its bomb payload had to be decreased as a
compensation and the aircraft could not carry any rockets.
The Petlyakov Pe-2 is a twin-engined dive bomber, also used as a heavy fighter,
night fighter, and reconnaissance aircraft.
The Bell P-39 Airacobra was developed in America and was one of the
main fighters used by the USA in the early part of the war. A number were
supplied to the Soviet Air Force through the lend-lease programme. Although
limited to low- and medium-altitude combat, it excelled on the Eastern Front
and in the South Pacific.
Introduced in 1941, the Lavochkin-Gorbunov-Gudkov LaGG-3 fighter aircraft
suffered from a number of shortcomings and technical issues, making it
extremely unpopular among Soviet pilots. In early 1943, it was replaced
by the much more capable Lavochkin La-5.
The Lavochkin La-5 replaced the extremely unpopular Lavochkin-Gorbunov-Gudkov
LaGG-3 in early 1943 and continued to be used until the end of World War Two.
Introduced in late 1944, the Lavochkin La-7 was a significant improvement
over the La-5. Despite the rather limited firepower of its 20mm cannons, it
was a dangerous opponent for any German late-war aircraft and continued to
be used during the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945.
Introduced in 1941, the Yakovlev Yak-1 turned out to be a fast and
maneuverable fighter which could hold its own against German aircraft
on the Eastern Front. This unit represents both the Yak-1 and the Yak-1B,
which was armed with a single 12.7mm machine gun instead of the two
7.62mm machine guns of the initial design.
Developed from the successful Yakovlev Yak-1 and Yak-1B, the Yak-3 had
one of the best power-to-weight ratios of all World War Two fighters. It
was introduced in June 1944 and armed with two 12.7mm Berezin UBS machine
guns and a single 20mm ShVAK cannon.
Initially designed as a two-seater training aircraft, the Yakovlev Yak-7
was turned into a single-pilot fighter as a reaction to the German invasion
of the Soviet Union and first deployed in late 1941. Just like the popular
Yak-1, it was a very capable fighter. Beginning in early 1943, it was
replaced by the Yak-9. This unit represents both the Yak-7 and Yak-7B.
Developed from the Yak-7, the Yakovlev Yak-9 was one of the best fighters
of World War Two and continued to be used in the Korean War. It was
introduced in late 1942. This unit represents all the Yak-9 fighter variants
which were armed with a 20mm ShVAK cannon and a 12.7mm Berezin UBS machine gun.
Developed from the Yak-7, the Yakovlev Yak-9 was one of the best fighters
of World War Two and continued to be used in the Korean War. The Yak-9B was
a fighter-bomber variant with an internal bomb bay behind the cockpit,
carrying a bomb load of up to 400 kg. Because of its disappointing
performance, only about 100 planes of this type were produced in early 1943.
Developed from the Yak-7, the Yakovlev Yak-9 was one of the best fighters
of World War Two and continued to be used in the Korean War. The Yak-9T was
a tank-buster variant, armed with a 37mm Nudelman-Suranov NS-37 cannon
instead of the 20mm ShVAK cannon. The 37mm cannon was also very effective
against German bombers. The Yak-9T first saw action during the Battle of
Kursk in July 1943.
Developed from the Yak-7, the Yakovlev Yak-9 was one of the best fighters
of World War Two and continued to be used in the Korean War. The Yak-9K was
a rare tank-buster variant, armed with a 45mm Nudelman-Suranov NS-45 cannon
instead of the 20mm ShVAK cannon. Its powerful recoil made it
extremely difficult to use the Yak-9K effectively, and only
about 50 were produced in 1944.
Introduced in 1942, the Lockheed P-38 Lightning was used as a
reconnaissance plane, fighter, and fighter-bomber. In dogfights it
relied on the speed provided by its twin engines, but was very
vulnerable in turning fights at low altitudes. It was eventually
replaced by the P-47 and P-51. This unit represents a fighter-bomber (
Close Air Support) variant, armed with bombs and rockets.
Introduced in 1942, the Lockheed P-38 Lightning was used as a
reconnaissance plane, fighter and fighter-bomber. In dogfights it
relied on the high speed provided by its twin engines, but was very
vulnerable in turning fights at low altitudes. It was eventually
replaced by the P-47 and P-51. This unit represents a fighter variant,
armed with multiple MGs and a 20mm cannon.
The North American P-51 Mustang was one of the most effective and
recognizable aircraft used by American forces. Over fifteen thousand were built,
and the aircraft served in both the Atlantic and Pacific theatres of the war.
This version has been modified to serve a close air support role.
The North American P-51 Mustang was one of the most effective and
recognizable aircraft used by American forces. Over fifteen thousand were built,
and the aircraft served in both the Atlantic and Pacific theatres of the war.
First used in 1942, the portable recoilless anti-tank rocket launcher
was an American invention, but a small number were given to Soviet forces
through the Lend-Lease programme. It launches a high-explosive anti-tank shaped charge.
The AMR 33 was designed as a cavalry tank, intended for light
reconnaissance.
The AMR 35 was a development of the AMR 33, adding a bigger engine and
improved suspension. Early models such as this were only armed with a
light machine gun.
The AMR 35 was a development of the AMR 33, adding a bigger engine and
improved suspension. Later models such as this were armed with a
13.2mm machine gun.
Designed in 1933 as a light infantry support tank, the Hotchkiss H35
was eventually adopted by the French cavalry as a light reconnaisance tank.
This early variant has a short main gun and an underpowered engine.
Designed in 1933 as a light infantry support tank, the Hotchkiss H35
was eventually adopted by the French cavalry as a light reconnaisance tank.
This later variant has been upgunned from the earlier model.
Designed as a light infantry tank, the R35 is well-protected
but its short 37mm main gun is slow to fire and lacks armour
penetration power.
Designed as a light infantry tank, the R35 is well-protected
but lacks armour penetration power, so later models such as
this have been fitted with a longer 37mm main gun.
The Renault R40 was an improvement of the R35, with a more reliable
drivetrain and a longer 37mm SA38 gun in a cast turret. Only a very small
number were produced by June 1940.
Originally produced in the early 1920s for the cavalry, this armed
half-track fulfilled a similar role as that of a light tank.
Intended to be the standard medium tank for French forces, the
S35 balanced a good gun, good armour, and speed.
The Hotchkiss H39 was an improved H35 with a more reliable and
powerful engine.
Designed in the 1930s, the AMC 35, or Automitrailleuse de
Combat Renault modele 1935, was a French cavalry tank with
limited production numbers. It was one of few French tanks
with a two-man turret, but by 1940 it was already outdated
and outclassed by most German tanks.
The FCM 36, or Char leger Modele 1936 FCM, was a French
infantry tank from the 1930s. About 100 FCM 36 tanks were
deployed against the Germans in 1940. Its crews were driven
to despair by its outdated 37mm gun and very small ammunition
storage.
Intended as a modern infantry support tank, the Renault Char D1 was
built between 1932 and 1935, but very poor reliability meant that its
use was relegated to France's colonies. A few were hastily shipped back to France in
June 1940 to help defend against the German invasion.
The Renault Char D2 was based on lessons learned in the development of the D1
and was intended to fulfill a similar role. This early model has a short 47mm main gun.
This later model of the Renault Char D2 has a longer 47mm main gun.
Designed as a Battle Tank, able to support infantry but also engage
enemy tanks, the Char B-1 was the largest and most heavily-armoured
fighting vehicle of its day. The bis variant was the only mass-produced
version, and added additional armour and a slightly better turret gun
compared to the prototype.
Originally intended to be an armoured mobile anti-tank gun,
the Laffly W15T Chasseur de Chars ended up being unarmoured so
that the vehicles could be completed and deployed to the front
as quickly as possible.
This was the standard scout vehicle for French forces in the early
war. Its powerful engine and relatively large 25mm main gun made it
an effective armoured car for the time.
The standard anti-tank gun of French forces during the early war.
Even though its design was finalized in 1934, by 1940 production was
still not sufficient to fulfill demand.
Designed to use a tungsten-cored AP round, this was the most powerful
anti-armour gun when it was delivered in 1939.
This artillery gun was the first modern artillery piece, and provided
the model for most artillery pieces of the early twentieth century. It
saw extended use during the Great War, and were still used at the outset of
the Second World War.
Designed as a mountain gun, these helped to equip mountain and
colonial artillery groups of the French army.
This is a howitzer gun, originally designed in 1935.
This French artillery piece was originally designed in the Great War, but is
still in widespread use around Europe.
This French heavy field howitzer was first used in the Great War, but
many pieces continue to be used, especially in coastal defenses or
with second-line forces.
Designed by the Swiss weapons firm Oerlikon, this was a heavier
anti-aircraft gun than earlier MG-based models.
Designed by the French weapons firm Hotchkiss, this was intended to be
the new standard anti-aircraft gun for the French military. By 1940,
however, only a few hundred had yet been distributed.
Initially designed just before the Great War, this was one
of the first self-propelled anti-aircraft guns. Its 75mm
gun mounted on a truck chassis is intended for use against
enemy aircraft, but often finds itself pressed into an anti-infantry
or even an anti-tank role.
Developed from a tank supply vehicle, the 38L was a stop-gap
armoured transport for mechanized infantry. Between the main vehicle
and its tracked trailer, it can carry ten men and their equipment.
Designed to transport a 10-man platoon cross country, this open-topped
truck was produced for the new mechanized divisions of the French army.
It was also used as a gun tractor.
Originally produced for the civilian market, these trucks were used to
transport supplies and troops.
Introduced in 1939, the Morane-Saulnier MS.406 was the most numerous
French fighter during World War Two. It was armed with a 20mm
Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon and two 7.5mm MAC 1934 machine guns.
Developed from the MS.406, the Morane-Saulnier MS.410 received a
stronger wing and a number of other improvements. It was equipped
with four rather than two 7.5mm MAC 1934 machine guns in addition to
the 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon. Only a tiny number was finished
when France fell, but its production was continued under German
supervision.
The Bloch MB.152 was one of the most common French planes during the
Battle of France. It was a sturdy fighter, but its unreliability and
inferior speed resulted in heavy losses against the Luftwaffe. This
unit also represents the similar MB.151. Both the MB.151 and MB.152
were armed with two 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannons and two 7.5mm MAC
1934 machine guns.
Introduced in the mid-1930s, the Dewoitine D.500 and its sub-variants
became one of the primary fighters of the French Air Force. It was also
exported to a number of nations around the world. However, during the
Battle of France the aircraft was no match for its German opponents. The
D.500 was armed with either two or four 7.7mm or 7.5mm machine guns.
Introduced in the mid-1930s, the Dewoitine D.500 and its sub-variants
became one of the primary fighters of the French Air Force. It was also
exported to a number of nations around the world. However, during the
Battle of France the aircraft was no match for its German opponents. The
D.501 was armed with a 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon and two machine
guns.
Introduced in the mid-1930s, the Dewoitine D.500 and its sub-variants
became one of the primary fighters of the French Air Force. It was also
exported to a number of nations around the world. The D.510 was equipped
with a more powerful engine than its predecessors and carried the same
armament as the D.501.
Introduced in early 1940, the Dewoitine D.520 was one of the most
successful French aircraft during the Battle of France. Unlike most other
French fighters, it could hold its own against its German opponents, but
only a small number was combat-ready by May 1940. The D.520 was armed with
a 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon and four 7.5mm MAC 1934 machine guns.
The Potez 630 and its sub-variants were French twin-engine aircraft used
in a variety of roles. The Potez 631 was a heavy, three-man fighter. This
early variant was armed with two forward-firing 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404
cannons and two rearward-firing 7.5 mm MAC 1934 machine guns.
The Potez 630 and its sub-variants were French twin-engine aircraft used
in a variety of roles. The Potez 631 was a heavy, three-man fighter. This
late variant was armed with two 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannons and six
7.5 mm MAC 1934 machine guns, four of which could fire forward.
The Potez 630 and its sub-variants were French twin-engine aircraft used
in a variety of roles. The Potez 633 was designed for close air support.
It could carry a bomb payload of up to 400 kilograms and was armed with
three 7.5 mm MAC 1934 machine guns, one of which could fire forward. It
was only used for a very short period of time during the Battle of France.
The Potez 630 and its sub-variants were French twin-engine aircraft used
in a variety of roles. The Potez 63.11 was meant to be a reconnaissance
aircraft, but was often pressed into a fighter or even close air support
role. It could carry a small bomb payload and was armed with multiple 7.5mm
machine guns, between three and seven of which could fire forward, depending
on the loadout.
Introduced in early 1940, the Caudron-Renault CR.714 quickly turned out
to be a disappointment. Its wooden construction and underpowered engine
seriously limited its operational capability. Nevertheless, several dozen
fighters of this type were flown by Free Polish pilots during the Battle
of France. The CR.714 was armed with four 7.5mm MAC 1934 machine guns.
Introduced in early 1940, the Loire-Nieuport LN.411 dive bomber saw
action during the Battle of France. Only a few dozen planes of this type
were built and most of them were already lost in May 1940. The LN.411 was
armed with a 20mm Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon, two 7.5mm Darne machine
guns and a bomb payload of up to 225 kg. This unit also represents the
similar LN.401 variant.
The M2 Light Tank was an interwar design that led to the development
of the M3 Stuart tank. It was only used in combat by the 1st Tank Battalion
of the US Marine Corps, and by British forces in Burma.
Compared to the M3, the M3A1 Stuart was equipped with a more
powerful engine, and had a few other minor improvements such as a
higher mount for the anti-aircraft machine gun.
Converted from the M3A1 Stuart, the Satan was a rare flame thrower
