tank used by the US Marine Corps in the Pacific. The 37mm main gun
was replaced with a Ronson F.U.L. Mk. IV flame thrower. The M3A1
Satan was first deployed during the landings on Saipan in June 1944.
The M3A3 Stuart was designed alongside the M5 and benefitted
from a new sloped hull armour design. It was also roomier and
carried additional ammunition as well as radio equipment.
The M5A1 was produced alongside the M3, and by 1943 would be the
most common variant of Stuart tank in American service. It has slightly improved
armour compared to the M3. By 1944 it was being outclassed by
most German tanks, and was used primarily for scouting purposes.
The M24 Chaffee Light Tank entered service in December 1944 and was
intended to replace the remaining M5 Stuarts. Despite its light
armour, it was very popular among the troops because of its mobility,
firepower and reliability. It continued to serve in multiple armies
around the world long after the end of the war.
With its hull-mounted 75mm gun, the M3 Lee brought some
much-needed firepower to the Allied forces in North Africa.
Some M3s were still used during the invasion of Sicily, but
their high profile, insufficient armour and inability to fire
the 75mm gun while Hull Down soon led to the decision to replace
them with M4 Sherman tanks.
The M3A1 Lee was a slight improvement over the original M3 variant.
It had a cast hull with slightly improved armour. Only about 300
tanks of this type were produced.
The M3A3 Lee received an engine upgrade compared to
earlier variants. Only about 300 tanks of this
variant were produced.
This extremely rare variant of the M3 Lee was equipped
with a powerful Chrysler A57 multibank engine, giving it
far better reliability and speed than the earlier variants.
The M3A5 was the final variant of the Lee. It used
the same engine as the M3A3, but had a riveted hull
with slightly more effective armour. About 600 M3A5 Lee
tanks were produced. Most of them were used by British
forces.
First designed in 1940, the M4 'Sherman' tank entered production
in 1942 and became the main battle tank for Allied forces in the
war. This is the welded hull design with a vision cupola for the
commander.
The M4A1 was the second version of the M4 design, but it ended up
entering production first in February 1942. It has a rounded, cast
hull, giving it extra protection on the front. This version has a
vision cupola for the commander.
This was a diesel-powered variant of the Sherman tank with a
General Motors twin G-41 engine. These were used by allied forces
as well as the American Marine corps.
The M4A3 has a welded hull and carries a powerful Ford GAA V8 engine.
It ended up being the most commonly used model in the American forces.
This version has a vision cupola for the commander.
These M4A3 Sherman tanks were modified by Navy engineers to replace
the main gun with a flamethrower. Known as Zippo or Ronson after
popular brands of lighters, Marines called them the Mark 1. Only a small
number saw action on Iwo Jima, but they were highly effective.
This is a later variant of the M4A3 with glacis front hull armour
and wet stowage for main gun rounds, reducing the chance of fire
from a ruptured shell casing. Some are built with Horizontal Volute
Spring Suspension, offering better traction. A Smoke Mortar is mounted
on the turret, fired by the Loader.
Designed to fulfill the role of a heavily armoured assault tank,
this is an up-armoured version of the M4A3 with a new turret.
A Smoke Mortar is mounted on the turret, fired by the Loader.
Designed to fulfill the role of a heavily armoured assault tank,
this is an up-armoured version of the M4A3 with a new turret. This
is a conversion of the standard 75mm gun to a 76mm gun.
A Smoke Mortar is mounted on the turret, fired by the Loader.
By 1942 it was clear that the 75mm gun on the Sherman was not
sufficient to penetrate newer, heavy tanks. By 1944 some models of
M4A1 were fitted with the 76mm gun, and these were rushed to France
soon after the Normandy landings.
This is a later variant of the M4A3, with a 76mm main gun and
wet stowage for main gun rounds. The variants with HVSS were
designated E8 and popularly known as 'Easy Eights'.
First designed in 1940, the M4 'Sherman' tank entered production
in 1942 and became the main battle tank for Allied forces in the
war. This late-war variant was equipped with a 105mm howitzer for
infantry support.
The M4A3 has a welded hull and carries a powerful Ford GAA V8 engine.
This rare variant was equipped with a 105mm howitzer for infantry support.
The M26 Pershing was the only heavy American tank deployed
in the war. In its few engagements, its 90mm main
gun turned out to be a formidable weapon even against heavy
German armour.
The M3 Gun Motor Carriage, an early American tank destroyer, was a lightly armoured half-track
equipped with an M1897A5 75mm gun. It served in the Philippines campaign,
the Pacific, North Africa, and in the Allied invasion of Sicily, but
was eventually replaced by the M10 Wolverine.
The M6 Gun Motor Carriage 'Fargo' was the first US tank
destroyer of the war. It had a 37mm gun mounted
on a Dodge WC 52 3/4 ton truck. While it was initially
considered a cost-effective mobile anti-tank weapon,
it soon fell into disfavor in North Africa because its
37mm gun turned out to be ineffective against German
tanks of the time.
Introduced in early 1943, the M10 GMC, nicknamed Wolverine, proved itself
as an effective tank destroyer against German targets.
Its open top, however, made it vulnerable to close-range infantry
attacks.
The M18 GMC 'Hellcat' was designed to be light and fast, and used
the light 76mm gun from the Sherman. Such speed comes at a cost,
however, and it only has minimal armour protection.
With its powerful main gun, the 90mm GMC M36 Jackson was
the most effective American WW2 tank destroyer. It was
significantly slower than the Hellcat, but its
reinforced front armour offered far better protection.
The M7 Priest was designed as a self-propelled 105mm howitzer,
using the chassis of an M3 Lee. It was first produced in
April 1942. It received the nickname 'Priest' because its
machine gun ring looked like a pulpit.
The M7 Priest was designed as a self-propelled 105mm howitzer,
using the chassis of an M3 Lee. It was first produced in
April 1942. It received the nickname 'Priest' because its
machine gun ring looked like a pulpit. Several thousand
were supplied to British forces trough Lend-lease.
This variant of the M7 Priest self-propelled 105mm howitzer
used an M4 Sherman instead of an M3 Lee chassis. Its
production began in March 1944.
This variant of the M7 Priest self-propelled 105mm howitzer
used an M4 Sherman instead of an M3 Lee chassis. Its
production began in March 1944. Several hundred also saw
limited use with Commonwealth and Polish forces.
Based on the M5 Stuart, the 75mm Howitzer Motor Carriage,
later nicknamed 'Scott,' was designed as an assault gun and to
provide mobile artillery support. It was used by American and Free
French forces in Europe, and by the Marines in the Pacific.
The M8 Greyhound first saw action during the Italian campaign. Its offroad
capabilities were disappointing compared to other armoured cars, but because
of its sturdiness, speed and low profile it was a useful asset nevertheless.
US forces used the M8 Greyhound for scouting missions and occasionally for
infantry support.
Derived from the M8 Greyhound, the M20 Utility Car served as a widespread
command and scout car among the US forces. It was only armed with a single
machine gun attached to a ring mount, but also equipped with one or two long
range radios. It was a common practice to store a Bazooka anti-tank weapon
inside the car for emergencies.
The Landing Vehicle, Tracked, is an amphibious vehicle developed to transport cargo
from ship to shore, but was later adapted as an armoured personnel carrier. The LVT-4
was designed in 1943, has a rear ramp for loading and unloading of passengers,
and can carry up to 30 troops.
These fire support LVTs were converted from LVT-2s, adding the turret
and gun from a M3 Light Tank, and two AAMGs mounted behind the turret.
This up-armoured LVT was based on the LVT-2, and adds the turret from the M8 HMC
to provide fire support. Its hull is enclosed in armour.
This was the standard anti-tank gun of US forces in
1942 and 1943. Its Canister round was very effective against
infantry targets, but its performance against German mid-war
tanks was disappointing, and in 1944 it was replaced by
more effective weapons.
This was the American adaptation of the British OQF 6-pounder.
The gun was distributed in preparation for Operation
Overlord, and was only supplied with AP ammunition.
The M5 3-inch AT Gun was the most powerful American anti-tank gun used
in World War 2. It was also sometimes used in an improvised artillery role.
However, the 3-inch gun was not very popular among US troops and commanders
due to its heavy weight.
The M1A1 Pack Howitzer was a light gun designed to be transported
across difficult terrain.
The M2A1 was the standard divisional artillery gun of most branches of
the US military during World War 2. Post-war it continued to be used,
now designated the M101A1.
The M1 155mm howitzer was the standard medium-sized artillery gun used by the
US Army in all theatres of World War 2.
This was the standard US heavy anti-aircraft gun of World
War 2. In the few instances in which it was used as an
improvised anti-tank gun, it was capable of inflicting
devastating damage with its armour-piercing ammunition.
This is a captured German PaK 38 gun in American service.
This is a captured German PaK 40 gun in American service.
This is a captured German PaK 43 gun in American service.
This is an 88mm German anti-aircraft gun, captured and redeployed
in American service.
Introduced in 1942, the American M3A1 Scout Car saw action in almost
all theatres of World War Two. It was used as both an armed reconnaissance
vehicle as well as a transport for small squads of troops.
Introduced in 1942, the American M3A1 Scout Car saw action in almost
all theatres of World War Two. It was used as both an armed reconnaissance
vehicle as well as a transport for small squads of troops. Almost 7000 were
given to Commonwealth forces as part of the Lend-Lease programme.
Introduced in 1942, the American M3A1 Scout Car saw action in almost
all theatres of World War Two. It was used as both an armed reconnaissance
vehicle as well as a transport for small squads of troops. More that 3000
were supplied to the USSR as part of the Lend-Lease programme.
The M3 half-track was one of the most common Allied armoured
personnel carriers in World War 2. It was open-topped and only
lightly armoured.
This variant of the M3 half-track is armed with an 81mm mortar
and intended to be used for mobile fire support. It saw service with
US and Free french armoured forces.
This later variant of the M3 halftrack has a .50-cal MG on a
ring mount, often referred to as a 'pulpit', in addition to
a .30-cal MG mounted on the passenger compartment.
The famous Willys MB Jeep was one of the most popular
off-road utility vehicles among the US forces and their
allies in World War 2.
The M29 Weasel was the American equivalent of the British Universal
Carrier. First used during the invasion of Italy, it soon became a very
popular personnel and supply carrier due to its excellent offroad
capabilities. It was also used by British and Commonwealth troops.
Produced by General Motors, the CCKW was the most common
truck of the US Army in World War 2. It was extremely versatile
and was used to transport weapons, supplies and infantry across
North Africa, Europe and various islands in the Pacific.
First used in 1942, the portable recoilless anti-tank rocket launcher
was an American invention and was mainly used by American forces
during the war. It launches a high-explosive anti-tank shaped charge.
The Douglass SBD Dauntless was a scout bomber aircraft manufactured from 1940
to 1944. It saw action in the South Pacific where it undertook dive bombing
attacks on Japanese ships.
The Grumman F4F Wildcat was a carrier-based fighter, and was the main
fighter aircraft in American Navy and Marine service during the
early part of the war.
The Curtiss P-40 Warhawk was designed in late 1930s, and played an important
role in American action in North Africa and in Southeast Asia.
The Republic P-47 Thunderbolt was one of the main fighter aircraft
used by American forces during the war.
Officially designated 'Tank, Light, Mk VI' this was the latest model
of light tank developed by Vickers-Armstrongs in 1936. This early
variant has a .303 and a .50 inch machine gun as its main armament.
Officially designated 'Tank, Light, Mk VI' this was the latest model
of light tank developed by Vickers-Armstrongs in 1936. This later
variant has a 15mm Besa machine gun as its main armament and an additional
7.92mm co-ax MG.
The M2 Light Tank was an interwar design that led to the development
of the M3 Stuart tank. Designed and produced in the USA, it was used in
small numbers by British forces in Burma.
The Stuart I Light Tank was built by the United States as the M3
and provided to the UK through the Lend-Lease programme from early 1941.
Its quick speed and ease of control led to its being nicknamed 'Honey'
by British tank crews in North Africa.
Compared to the Mk I, the Stuart III (or M3A1 Stuart) was equipped
with a more powerful engine, and had a few other minor improvements
such as a higher mount for the anti-aircraft machine gun. It was
introduced in October 1942.
The Stuart Mk VI was the British designation for the M5 and M5A1.
The 37mm gun of the Stuart was not powerful enough to deal with
the German tanks commonly encountered in 1944 and 1945 effectively.
Because of this, British forces used the Stuart primarily for scouting
purposes, even more so than American units.
The A9 was the first of a series of tanks designed for mobility and
for engaging with enemy tanks.
The A9 was the first of a series of tanks designed for mobility and
for engaging with enemy tanks. The Close Support variant was intended
to support attacks with its 3.7" howitzer main gun.
The A10 was initially intended to be an infantry support tank,
but its light armour meant that it was pressed into a cruiser role.
The A10 was initially intended to be an infantry support tank,
but its light armour meant that it was pressed into a cruiser role.
This is the Close Support variant, armed with a 3.7 inch howitzer.
The A13 was inspired by the Russian BT tank and based on the design
of the American Christie tank. First designed in 1937, it is fast but
suffers from very light armour and an unreliable engine.
The A13 was inspired by the Russian BT tank and based on the design
of the American Christie tank. The Mk II has additional armour protection
but suffers from an unreliable engine.
The Crusader was rushed into production in August 1939, and although
was better armoured than other early British tanks, it still carried
a relatively light 2pdr gun. It is prone to breakdown, especially in the harsh desert
environment.
This variant of Crusader tank is intended for close support of infantry,
and has a 3-inch howitzer as its main armament.
The Mk II variant of the Crusader was introduced in 1942. The small MG
turret at the front of the hull was removed and the armour was reinforced.
The tank was still prone to breakdown in the North African desert
environment and it still relied on the now-outdated OQF 2-pounder.
This is the close support variant of the Crusader Mk II,
armed with a 3-inch howitzer.
Armed with the OQF 6-pounder, the Mk III variant was much
more effective against the German tanks of the Afrika Korps.
However, the price of the larger main gun was a decrease in
ammunition and the removal of the loader, reducing the crew
to three. Production began in May 1942 and the first units
saw action in October 1942.
This anti-aircraft variant of the Crusader was armed with a 40mm
Bofors AA gun and two AAMGs. It was not designed to fight ground
forces.
This anti-aircraft variant of the Crusader was armed
with twin 20mm Oerlikon AA guns. They could also be used
to fight infantry. This unit also represents the AA Mk III
variant, which had the same armament.
The Matilda was developed as an infantry support tank, and as such is
heavily-armoured but carries only a Vickers .303 machine gun.
The Matilda was developed as an infantry support tank, and the Mark II
variant was larger and more heavily armoured than the original. Though well-protected, it
is rather slow and still mounts the OQF 2 pdr gun. It was also supplied to the Soviets and
used for infantry support.
The Matilda was developed as an infantry support tank, and the Mark II
variant was larger and more heavily armoured than the original. This
Close Support variant mounts a QF 3-inch howitzer.
The Matilda Frog was an Australian flame thrower variant of the
Matilda II. The OQF 2-pounder main gun and the loader position were
removed to make room for the flame thrower and its fuel tanks. About
two dozen Matilda Frogs were deployed on Borneo in 1945.
First designed in 1938, this design suddenly gained favour on the
eve of war in 1939. Although slow and lacking a dedicated Commander
position, its reliability and armour helped it become one of the
most valued British tanks in North Africa. Large numbers were also
supplied to the Soviets.
The Valentine Mk III was equipped with a larger three-man
turret, which made it much easier for the crew to operate
the main gun. However, the side armour had to be reduced
as a compensation for the increased weight.
Because of the shortage of British engines, some Valentines
were built with GMC diesel engines connected to an American
transmission, giving them more reliability but less operational
range. The Mk IV variant is a Mk II with such an upgraded engine.
Because of the shortage of British engines, some Valentines
were built with GMC diesel engines connected to an American
transmission, giving them more reliability but less operational
range. The Mk V variant is a Mk III with such an upgraded engine.
The Valentine Mk VIII was an upgunned Mk III variant with an
OQF 6-pounder. In order to make room for the larger main gun,
the co-axial Besa machine gun and the loader had to be removed.
The British army only used a few of these tanks starting with
Operation Torch in November 1942 because they were soon replaced
by the Mk IX, which had a more powerful US-built engine.
The Valentine Mk IX was an upgunned Mk V variant with an
OQF 6-pounder. In order to make room for the larger main gun,
the co-axial Besa machine gun and the gunner position had to be removed.
It was first deployed during Operation Torch in November 1942.
The Valentine Mk X was similar to the Mk IX variant, but
it received a redesigned turret which allowed to reintroduce
the co-axial Besa machine gun. The turret still only had room
for two crewmen. It was only used as a command tank and usually
not deployed in direct combat.
This rare late variant of the Valentine was the only one still
deployed on the frontlines in the last two years of the war.
It was armed with a 75mm gun and restricted to unit commanders.
This is the British designation of the American M3 Lee. With
its hull-mounted 75mm gun, the M3 brought some much-needed
firepower to the Allied forces in North Africa, but because of its
high profile, insufficient armour and inability to fire the 75mm
gun while hull down it was later replaced by the M4 Sherman.
This is the British designation for the M3A1 Lee, which was a
slight improvement over the M3 (or Grant I) variant. It had a
cast hull with slightly improved armour. Only about 300 tanks
of this variant were produced.
The M3A3 Lee (or Lee V) received an engine upgrade compared
to earlier Lee/Grant variants. Only about 300 tanks of this
variant were produced.
This extremely rare variant of the M3 Lee/Grant was equipped
with a powerful Chrysler A57 multibank engine, giving it
far better reliability and speed than the earlier variants.
This was the final variant of the Lee/Grant. It used the
same engine as the M3A3 (or Lee V), but had a riveted hull
with slightly more effective armour. About 600 M3A5 Lee
(or Grant V) tanks were produced. Most of them were used by
British troops.
The Ram medium tank was designed and built in Canada from 1941 as a crusier
tank. Nearly 2000 of all marks were eventually built, but since the Sherman
was adopted as the standard tank for Canadian armoured forces, the Ram was
only used for training, as a cut-down APC, and as a command vehicle.
This version of the Ram tank was produced from February 1942, when enough
6-pounder guns were available.
The Sherman I was the British and Commonwealth designation for the
M4. Units in Commonwealth service did not have a loader hatch nor
a vision cupola for the commander.
The Sherman II was the British and Commonwealth designation for the
M4A1. Units in Commonwealth service did not have a loader hatch nor
a vision cupola for the commander.
The Sherman V was the British and Commonwealth designation for the
M4A4. Units in Commonwealth service did not have a loader hatch nor
a vision cupola for the commander.
Inspired by the Churchill Crocodile, this rare flame thrower
variant of the Sherman V saw limited action in
Germany in 1945. The flame thrower was located in the hull and
replaced the bow machine gun. The flame thrower fuel was stored in
an external trailer.
The Sherman IC Hybrid 'Firefly' was a standard M4A1 tank converted to carry
a 17pdr main gun, with far superior armour penetration power compared
to standard 75mm guns. Because of the large size of the main gun ammo,
the assistant driver position and its BMG has been removed.
The Sherman VC 'Firefly' was a standard M4A4 tank converted to carry
a 17pdr main gun, with far superior armour penetration power compared
to standard 75mm guns. Because of the large size of the main gun ammo,
the assistant driver position and its BMG has been removed.
The Cromwell tank was faster and smaller than the M4 Sherman, but it
did not benefit from sloped armour. This early variant still relied
on the OQF 6-pounder as its main armament. It was only produced in
small numbers.
The Cromwell tank was faster and smaller than the M4 Sherman, but it
did not benefit from sloped armour. The Mk IV was its most common
variant, armed with a 75mm gun.
This close support variant of the Cromwell was armed with
an OQF 95mm howitzer. It was only produced in small numbers.
Derived from the Cromwell, the Challenger was armed with the
powerful OQF 17-pounder. However, its turret armour and mobility
had to be reduced to compensate for the increased weight of the
main gun.
Developed from the Cromwell tank, the Comet was equipped with a
modified version of the OQF 17-Pounder gun that used shorter ammo. The Comet
was slower but more reliable than the Cromwell and received additional
armour protection. It only saw action during the final months of the
Allied advance into Germany.
The Churchill Mk I was armed with an OQF 2-pounder and a hull-mounted
3-inch howitzer. It saw action in the Dieppe Raid, in Tunisia, and Italy,
but only about 300 tanks of this Churchill variant were ever built.
The Churchill Mk II was a revision of the Mk I, sometimes called the Mk Ia,
that replaced the hull-mounted howitzer with a 7.92mm Besa machine gun.
It saw action in the Dieppe Raid, in Tunisia, and Italy.
About 1,100 tanks of this Churchill variant were built in 1941 and 1942.
Churchill Mk II 'Oke' was a special modification that
added a hull-mounted flamethrower located to the left
of the Assistant Driver's position. Three such tanks
were part of the Dieppe raid in August 1942.
The Mark III mounted a 6-pdr gun as its main armament.
The Mark IV is virtually identical to the earlier Mark III, the
only difference being that the Mark IV has a cast turret.
In Tunisia, some Churchill Mark IIIs and IVs had their original OQF 6-pounder gun
replaced with an American 75mm gun from a destroyed Sherman or the British QF 75mm gun.
This gave them a much better HE round. As many as 200 of this North African (NA) variant
were created and served in Italy.
This Churchill variant is armed with an OQF 95mm howitzer for
close infantry support.
This variant was equipped with a 75mm gun, more effective than the
6pdr mounted on earlier models. Churchill Mark IVs that were upgraded
with this gun were functionally the same, and known as Churchill IV NA(75).
The Churchill Mk VII received a significant armour upgrade
compared to earlier variants and was equipped with an
OQF 75mm gun.
This is the close support variant of the heavily armoured
Churchill Mk VII, equipped with a 95mm howitzer.
This is the Armoured Vehicle Royal Engineers (AVRE) variant of the
Churchill Mk IV. Instead of the main turret gun, it is armed with a
Petard heavy mortar that can only fire at close-range targets.
The Churchill Crocodile was a conversion kit for MK VII Churchills
which replaced the hull MG with a flamethrower. 500 of these vehicles
were produced and used between 1944 and 1945.
This is a captured Italian M11 tank, redeployed in British service.
This is an Italian M13 tank, captured and redeployed in British service.
This is an Italian M14/41 tank, captured and redeployed in British service.
This is a Morris CS 15cwt truck, captured from the British, with a
Breda 20mm AA gun mounted on the truckbed, then re-captured and deployed
in British service.
The Sexton was a self-propelled OQF 25-pounder howitzer. It was
produced in Canada and first deployed in Italy in September 1943.
It was open-topped and only lightly armoured because its task was
to provide artillery support from a safe distance.
The Bishop was a self-propelled OQF 25-pounder howitzer.
Introduced in late 1942, it was used in North Africa and
during the early parts of the Italian campaign. It was a slow,
unreliable vehicle which suffered from a lack of gun elevation.
Because of this, the Bishop was only produced in small numbers.
This is a 40mm Bofors anti-aircraft gun mounted on a
Morris C9/B truck.
Originally intended simply as a motorized transport for the 2 pdr gun,
in North Africa crews often fired the gun from the back of its
transport truck. The only restriction is that it cannot fire
in the same direction as the truck's hull.
Just like the OQF 2-pounder, the 6-pounder was sometimes
fired from the back of a truck to combine mobility and
firepower. However, the increased weight of the gun had a
tendency to slow down the vehicle. The gun could not fire
in the same direction as the truck's hull.
This was the British designation for the American M10 Wolverine
tank destroyer, which was also used by British armoured forces.
With its 3-inch gun, the M10 was a serious threat to German tanks,
but its open top made it vulnerable to infantry and it was rather
slow for a tank destroyer.
The Achilles was a British conversion of the American M10
Wolverine tank destroyer. It was equipped with the powerful
OQF 17-pounder gun, and reinforced with additional armour plates
on the front and sides of the hull.
The Archer was a British self-propelled OQF 17-Pounder based on the chassis
of the Valentine tank. It had an unusual design as it used a rear-facing gun,
making it useful for setting up ambushes but a poor choice for engaging
targets on the advance. It was introduced in late 1944.
Converted from Morris 4x2 15-cwt trucks, these armoured cars were
built as a stop-gap measure to supply the BEF. This early model is
armed with a co-axial machine gun.
Designed as a scout vehicle, this small, two-man 4WD vehicle is
primarily intended for reconnaisance and transporting small teams.
First deployed during the Great War, these armoured cars were used
during the interwar period by security forces in the British Empire.
These vehicles have been modified for desert warfare with an open-
topped turret.
This was a South African-designed armoured car, intended for domestic
defense. When war broke out in North Africa, this model was the only
Commonwealth-produced Armoured Car available in significant numbers.
This was a South African-designed armoured car, intended for domestic
defense. When war broke out in North Africa, this model was the only
commonwealth-produced Armoured Car available in significant numbers.
This model has additional armour on the front of the hull.
The product of mounting an earlier armoured car body on to an
artillery tractor chassis, the Humber armoured car was widely used
by British and Commonwealth forces in North Africa. This mark II
variant has a smaller, two-man turret.
The product of mounting an earlier armoured car body on to an
artillery tractor chassis, the Humber armoured car was widely used
by British and Commonwealth forces throughout World War 2. This
variant was armed with an American 37mm gun in addition to its
co-axial machine gun.
The Associated Equipment Company (AEC) armoured car had far
better armour protection than other armoured cars at the time.
This variant was used in North Africa and was equipped with an
OQF 2-pounder and a co-axial machine gun.
The Associated Equipment Company (AEC) armoured car had far
better armour protection than other armoured cars at the time.
This variant first saw action during the Italian campaign and was
equipped with an OQF 6-pounder and a co-axial machine gun.
The Associated Equipment Company (AEC) armoured car had far
better armour protection than other armoured cars at the time.
This variant first saw action during the Italian campaign and was
equipped with a 75mm gun and a co-axial machine gun.
First used during the Allied invasion of Italy, the Otter was the
most common Canadian-produced armoured car in World War 2.
The Staghound was a US-produced armoured car entirely meant
to be exported to allied countries. As such, it was used by
British, Commonwealth and Free Polish troops, amongst others,
beginning with the invasion of Sicily in July 1943.
Developed alongside the Dingo Scout Car, the Daimler Armoured
Car, which saw first action in mid-1941, was equipped with a
turret mounting an OQF 2-pounder. British recon units deployed
it together with the Dingo in North Africa, Europe and Southeast
Asia throughout the war.
With a tripod mounting, a 40mm gun, and a fast rate of
fire, the 2pdr is one of the best anti-tank guns of the early war.
The OQF 6-pounder anti-tank gun was introduced in April 1942 to
replace the OQF 2-pounder, which was no longer considered
powerful enough to penetrate the armour of most German tanks.
First deployed in February 1943, the OQF 17-pounder was the most
powerful British anti-tank gun in WW2. It was capable of destroying
all but the most heavily armoured German tanks.
This was the standard artillery piece of the British forces in the
Great War, and it continues to be used in the early part of the
Second World War.
Designed as a replacement for the Great War-era 18pdr, the earliest
25pdr guns were conversions of the earlier model. It quickly became
the standard artillery piece of British and Commonwealth forces.
First built for use in the Great War, substantial numbers of these
guns were still in service as of 1940.
First designed in 1934, this was the standard heavy anti-aircraft gun
of Commonwealth forces throughout the war.
This is a 20mm Italian AA gun, captured and redeployed in British service.
This is an Italian 47mm anti-tank and infantry support gun, captured
and redeployed in British service.
This is a captured PaK 38 gun, redeployed in British service.
This is a German PaK 40 anti-tank gun, captured and redeployed in
British service.
This is an 88mm German anti-aircraft gun, captured and redeployed
in British service.
The Universal Carrier was developed in 1940 as a small, light, but
armoured transport for small teams armed with support weapons. It was also supplied
to the USSR through the lend-lease programme. This variant has a Bren
machine gun mounted in the bow.
The Universal Carrier was developed in 1940 as a small, light, but
armoured transport for small teams armed with support weapons.
It was also supplied to the USSR through the lend-lease programme. This
variant has an anti-tank rifle mounted in the bow.
Originally built in Canada as the Ram tank, these were used for
training but never deployed in battle. In 1944 as British and Commonwealth
forces sought an armoured troop carrier, the turrets of these tanks were
removed and the hulls used to transport soldiers into combat.
Also known as the R-Type, this truck was originally designed for
civilian commercial service, but was used by some British companies
during the early years of the war.
The Ford F15 was one of the so-called Military Pattern trucks
produced in Canada to outfit British and Commonwealth forces
throughout World War 2.
Developed from rifle-mounted AT grenades, the Projector, Infantry, Anti
Tank (PIAT) fires a shaped charge by means of a heavy spring.
The Hawker Hurricane was one of the most numerous British and
Commonwealth fighters in World War Two. The Mk I variant was
armed with eight 7.7mm Browning machine guns.
The Hawker Hurricane was one of the most numerous British and
Commonwealth fighters in World War Two. The Mk IIB variant was
armed with twelve 7.7mm Browning machine guns and was able to
carry two 250- or 500-pound bombs. It was also provided to the
Soviet Union through the lend-lease programme.
The Hawker Hurricane was one of the most numerous British and
Commonwealth fighters in World War Two. The Mk IIC variant was
a dedicated fighter-bomber, equipped with four 20mm Hispano Mk II
cannons and two 250- or 500-pound bombs.
The Hawker Hurricane was one of the most numerous British and
Commonwealth fighters in World War Two. The Mk IID variant was
a dedicated tank hunter, equipped with two 40mm Rolls Royce or
Vickers S cannons and a single 7.7mm Browning machine gun.
The Hawker Typhoon was introduced in 1941 as a replacement for the Hurricane.
The Hawker Tempest was an improved version of the Typhoon, with
a more powerful engine and better performance at high altitudes.
The Supermarine Spitfire was one of the most popular British
fighters in World War 2. This unit represents the early variants,
most of which were equipped with eight 7.7mm Browning machine guns.
The Supermarine Spitfire was one of the most popular British
fighters in World War 2. This unit represents the Mk V variants,
most of which were armed with four 7.7mm Browning machine guns,
two 20mm Hispano II cannons and a bomb payload of up to 500 pounds.
Some Spitfires of this type were also provided to the Soviet Union
through the lend-lease programme.
The Supermarine Spitfire was one of the most popular British
fighters in World War 2. This unit represents the Mk IX (and similar)
variants, most of which were armed with two 7.7mm Browning machine
guns, two 20mm Hispano II cannons and a bomb payload of up to 1000 pounds.
Some Spitfires of this type were also provided to the Soviet Union
through the lend-lease programme.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. The Finnish troops used a small number of these
outdated tanks during the Winter War. This model has a short-barreled
37mm main gun.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. The Finnish troops used a small number of these
outdated tanks during the Winter War. This model is armed with a
Finnish variation of the air-cooled Maxim M/09-31 machine gun.
First built in 1928, the Vickers Mark E was designed in Britain
but all production models were licensed and built abroad. This is
the Finnish upgraded version, with a new turret, a 37mm Bofors gun,
and a 9mm hull submachinegun.
Developed in the early 1930s, the T-37A amphibious tankette
was deployed by the Red Army during the invasion of Poland,
the Winter War and the first months of the German attack on
the Soviet Union. This T-37A has been captured and redeployed
by Finnish soldiers.
Captured from the USSR during the Winter War, several models of T-26 tank
have been returned to service in the Finnish armed forces.
Captured from the USSR during the Winter War, several models of T-26 tank
have been returned to service in the Finnish armed forces. This is a
later model with improved armour.
Captured from the USSR during the Winter War, several models of T-26 tank
have been returned to service in the Finnish armed forces. This is an
OT-133 flame thrower tank, based on the 1939 variant of the T-26.
Numerous Soviet BT-5 tanks were captured and quickly redeployed
in Finnish service.
Many Soviet BT-7 tanks were captured and redeployed in Finnish service.
A handful of up-armoured T-28 tanks were captured during the Winter War
and later deployed in two platoons.
The T-34 was the most advanced tank of the early war, and its combination
of a 76mm gun and heavy armour made it a formidable foe. This T-34 of the
early 1940 variant has been captured and redeployed by Finnish soldiers.
A small number of KV-1 heavy tanks were captured during the Continuation
War and redeployed in Finnish service.
Built upon a modified T-70 hull, the SU-76M was intended to serve as
a combination assault gun and tank destroyer. This vehicle has been
captured and redeployed by Finnish soldiers.
This Soviet ISU-152 assault gun has been captured and redeployed by
Finnish soldiers.
Finland purchased about 15 Panzer IV J tanks from Nazi Germany, but
they arrived too late to see action against the Red Army. Instead, the
Finnish army ended up using these tanks against German soldiers during
the Lapland War.
The StuG III is an assault gun built upon a Panzer III chassis.
Finland purchased around 60 StuGs of the G variant in 1943 and 1944.
Created from captured Soviet BT-7 tanks, the BT-42 is the first
Finnish-built assault gun. It mounts a British 4.5-inch howitzer
from the Great War.
Several Soviet BA-10s, an improved version of the BA-6, were captured
during the Winter War and put into Finnish service.
This was the designation for the 3.7 cm PaK 36 in Finnish service.
Captured in the Winter War, this Soviet AT gun was designated the PstK/32
when it was deployed with Finnish forces.
This is the Finnish designation for the PaK 38 AT gun.
This is the Finnish designation for the German PaK 97/38 anti-tank gun.
This is the Finnish designation for the German PaK 40.
Designed in Russia, this gun saw action in the Russo-Japanese War
and the Great War. Finland only possesses a small number of these.
This is the Finnish designation for the 76mm regimental gun M1927.
Originally a Soviet design, many were captured during the Winter War.
This is the Finnish designation for the German-built 10.5cm leFH 18.
Originally built by the French, this 105mm gun has been adapted
for use by many armed forces around the world.
This was the Finnish designation for captured and redeployed Soviet
122mm M1938 howizers.
This was the Finnish designation for the German-built 15cm sFH 18.
This was the Finnish designation for the German 2cm FlaK 38 light anti-aircraft gun.
This is the Finnish designation for the 40mm anti-aircraft gun produced
by the Swedish arms manufacturer AB Bofors.
The Fokker C.X was a biplane designed and built in the Netherlands. The Finnish
army used them for reconnaisance and as light bombers.
The Fiat G.50 fighter was Italy's first single-seat, all-metal monoplane
with an enclosed cockpit and a retractable landing gear. It was exported
to several other nations, including Finland. In Finnish service, the G.50
saw action against the Red Army during the Winter War and Continuation War.
Introduced in 1939, the Morane-Saulnier MS.406 was the most numerous
French fighter during World War Two. Almost 100 planes of this type
were exported or delivered to Finland and deployed against the Red Army
in the Winter and Continuation Wars. The MS.406 was armed with a 20mm
Hispano-Suiza HS.404 cannon and two 7.5mm MAC 1934 machine guns.
The Morane-Saulnier MS.410 was developed from the MS.406. It received
a stronger wing and two additional 7.5mm machine guns among other
improvements. A small number of MS.410 fighters was delivered to
Finland and served in the Winter and Continuation Wars.
The Morko-Morane was a modified Finnish version of the French
Morane-Saulnier MS.406. It was equipped with a much more powerful,
Soviet engine along with other improvements. Most Morko-Moranes were
armed with four machine guns and a single 20mm cannon. They saw
limited action in the Continuation and Lapland Wars.
Italy's first mass-produced tank, the Fiat 3000
was an infantry tank based on the Renault FT. It
had a more spacious turret and a longer gun plus a
Fiat engine. It served throughout the war.
Developed from the British Mark VI tankette, this model was adopted
by Italian forces in 1929. Although it only has a machinegun and is
very lightly armoured, it is the most common armoured fighting vehicle
in the Italian army.
Some L3 tankettes have been modified in the field, removing the MG and replacing
it with a Solothurn 20mm anti-tank rifle.
Developed from the British Mark VI tankette, the L3/33 was adopted
by Italian forces in 1929. The Lf variant is armed with a flamethrower,
making it a highly effective anti-infantry vehicle.
Developed from the British Mark VI tankette, the L3/33 was adopted
by Italian forces in 1929. The Lf variant is armed with a flamethrower,
and this sub-variant has an external fuel tank mounted on a trailer
giving it more ammo capacity.
An upgrade to the L3/35 developed in 1938, a limited number of
tanks were converted and saw service in 1943. The twin 8mm
machine guns have been replaced by a single 13.2mm machine gun.
The L3/38 also has torsion bar suspension which reduces friction
and increases the tank's reliability.
First produced in 1939, the L6 was an attempt to develop a replacement
for the L3 tankette. Although an effective armoured reconnaissance
vehicle, it was already outclassed by the time of its introduction.
Designed in 1943, the P26/40 was the only Italian heavy tank deployed
in World War Two. It was armed with an Ansaldo 75mm L/34 gun and two
8mm Breda 38 machine guns. Only very few P26/40 tanks were used by
Italian troops. Most of them ended up being seized by the German forces
after the Armistice of Cassibile.
Designed as a light infantry tank, the R35 is well-protected
but its short 37mm main gun is slow to fire and lacks armour
penetration power. Germany gave 124 captured R35s to Italy in 1942.
Designed to be the main medium battle tank of the Italian army,
the M11 was under-armoured and its hull-mounted 37 anti-armour gun
proved difficult to use effectively.
Developed from the M11, the M13 added a more powerful 47mm gun and
a powered-traverse turret. From 1941 onward it became the standard
medium tank in the Italian forces.
The M14/41 was a slightly improved version of the M13/40 with a more
powerful diesel engine, a new lever for mud driving and a reworked
wheel drive. It entered service in mid-1942.
The Semoventes were Italian tank destroyers, designed on
the model of the German StuG. Despite the
disappointing performance of its main gun and its lack of
any secondary armament, the Semovente da 47/32 was deployed
on the Eastern Front, in North Africa, and in Italy.
Introduced in January 1942, the Semovente da 75/18 was a dangerous threat to Allied
tanks in North Africa. It was also often used in an improvised
artillery role.
Developed in 1942, the Semovente da 75/34 mounted a 75mm gun on
the chassis of a M15/42 tank. Only 141 were built, and it only saw
action in the defense of Rome in September 1943.
The Semovente da 90/53 mounted a 90mm anti-aircraft gun on a modified
M14/41 tank chassis. Only 30 were produced, owing to a shortage of
guns. These units proved highly effective in North Africa.
The Semovente da 105/25 mounts a 105mm gun on a modified
M42 chassis, giving it a lower profile. Over 100 were built
and some were deployed in the defense of Rome in 1943.
A few obsolete Lancia 1Z armoured cars built for WW1 were still in use
with the Italian Royal Army during World War II. In 1940 and 1941,
some were used in the East and North Africa campaigns. Later in the war,
Axis forces used them in anti-partisan policing duties.
The Autoblindo 40 was the first of a series of armoured cars produced
for the Italian army. It combines speed with good off-road capability.
This early model has a pair of 8mm machine guns in the turret and an
anti-aircraft machine gun mounted on the top of the turret.
The Autoblindo 41 was the second of a series of armoured cars produced
for the Italian army. It combines speed with good off-road capability.
This model has a 20mm gun as its main armament, as well as an
anti-aircraft machine gun mounted on the top of the turret.
The Camioneta SPA-Viberti AS 42 was a scout car with
a low profile, excellent mobility and offroad capability.
It was introduced in late 1942. This variant is armed with
a Breda 20/65 anti-aircraft gun in the centre and a machine
gun at the rear.
The Camioneta SPA-Viberti AS 42 was a scout car with
a low profile, excellent mobility and offroad capability.
It was introduced in late 1942. This variant is armed with
a Breda 20/65 anti-aircraft gun.
The Camioneta SPA-Viberti AS 42 was a scout car with
a low profile, excellent mobility and offroad capability.
It was introduced in late 1942. This is a lightly armed
variant with a rotatable machine gun.
The Camioneta SPA-Viberti AS 42 was a scout car with
a low profile, excellent mobility and offroad capability.
It was introduced in late 1942. This variant is armed with
a 47mm AT gun in the centre and a machine gun at the rear.
First adopted in 1935, this is the standard Italian AA gun, but it's
also used as an anti-personnel gun and as a light anti-tank gun.
This was an Italian licensed version of the German PaK 35/36.
An Austrian design produced under license in Italy, this gun was
intended as an anti-tank and infantry support gun.
This Austrian AT Gun is best known for being produced under license in
Italy as the 47/32. However, some pieces were also reused by the Germans
after their annexation of Austria. Additional pieces were obtained from
the conquest of the Netherlands, from the Soviet-controlled Baltic countries
and finally, from the annexation of Italy.
This mountain gun was first used in the Great War, and continues to
be used as a close support weapon for infantry.
Originally built for the Great War, this was a licenced copy of the
Krupp 1906 gun. It became the standard light artillery piece for
Italian forces in the war.
Originally built by Skoda in Austro-Hungary, many of these howitzers
were taken over by Italy in 1918.
This is an Italian license-built version of the French 105mm modele
This is a Morris CS 15cwt truck, captured from the British, with a
Breda 20mm AA gun mounted on the truckbed.
This was a medium truck designed and build by the FIAT company for use
in the Italian armed forces.
Produced by Fiat Avitazione, the Falco is a biplane fighter.
Known as the Picchiatello in Italian service, the Junkers Ju 87 was
a German dive-bomber.
Developed in 1935, the Breda Ba.65 was an Italian ground attack aircraft
which saw action during the Spanish Civil War and the early stages of
World War Two. It was armed with two 12.7mm and two 7.7mm Breda-SAFAT
machine guns and could carry a bomb payload of up to 600 kilograms.
The Fiat G.50 fighter was Italy's first single-seat, all-metal monoplane
with an enclosed cockpit and a retractable landing gear. During World
War Two, it saw action over Northern Europe, North Africa, the Balkans,
and the Italian mainland. It was armed with two 12.7mm Breda-SAFAT
machine guns and could carry a bomb payload of up to 200 kilograms.
Introduced in mid-1943, the Ro.57 was an Italian twin-engine fighter.
It arrived too late to take part in the North African campaign and saw
only little action before the Armistice of Cassibile in September 1943.
This fighter variant is armed with two 12.7mm Breda-SAFAT machine guns.
Introduced in mid-1943, the Ro.57 was an Italian twin-engine fighter.
It arrived too late to take part in the North African campaign and saw
only little action before the Armistice of Cassibile in September 1943.
This dedicated ground attack variant is armed with two 12.7mm Breda-SAFAT
machine guns, two 20mm cannons and a bomb payload of up to 500 kilograms.
The Macchi C.200 flew more sorties than any other Italian aircraft during
World War Two. It was used both in a fighter and fighter-bomber role. This
unit represents the dedicated fighter variant and is armed with two 12.7mm
Breda-SAFAT machine guns.
The Macchi C.200 flew more sorties than any other Italian aircraft during
World War Two. It was used both in a fighter and fighter-bomber role. This
unit represents the dedicated fighter-bomber variant and is armed with two
12.7mm Breda-SAFAT machine guns and a bomb payload of up to 320 kilograms.
Developed from the Macchi C.200, the C.202 received a new engine and
fuselage along with a number of other improvements. It was armed with two
12.7mm and two optional 7.7mm Breda-SAFAT machine guns. The C.202 was
introduced in late 1941 and saw action in all World War Two theatres with
Italian involvement.
Despite its significant performance advantages over other contemporary
Italian aircraft, most Reggiane Re.2000 fighters were exported to other
countries. Only a small number was kept in Italy to intercept Allied
planes over the Mediterranean. The Re.2000 was armed with two 12.7mm
Breda-SAFAT machine guns.
Developed from the Re.2000, the Re.2001 was introduced in mid-1941.
The Italian Regia Aeronautica used it both in a fighter and
fighter-bomber role over Italy and the Mediterranean. It was armed
with two 12.7mm and two 7.7mm Breda-SAFAT machine guns. This unit
represents the Serie I variant.
Developed from the Re.2000, the Re.2001 was introduced in mid-1941.
The Italian Regia Aeronautica used it both in a fighter and
fighter-bomber role over Italy and the Mediterranean. The CB variant
was first produced in 1942 and could carry a bomb payload of around
500 kilograms.
Developed from the Re.2000, the Re.2001 was introduced in mid-1941.
The Italian Regia Aeronautica used it both in a fighter and
fighter-bomber role over Italy and the Mediterranean. The CN Serie III
and IV variants were armed with two 20mm Mauser MG 151/20 cannons and
could carry a bomb payload of up to 640 kilograms.
Developed from the Re.2001 fighter, the Re.2002 was a dedicated ground
attack aircraft, armed with two 12.7mm and two 7.7mm Breda-SAFAT machine
guns as well as a bomb payload of almost 1,000 kilograms. It saw action
against the Allies in Sicily and continued to be used by both the Germans
and the Italian Co-Belligerent Air Force after the Armistice of Cassibile.
The CR.32 was an Italian biplane fighter which saw action during
the Spanish Civil War and the early parts of World War Two. In early
1941, its losses against Allied aircraft over North Africa and
the Mediterranean resulted in the decision to withdraw it from active
service. The CR.32 was armed with either two 7.7mm or 12.7mm Breda-SAFAT
machine guns and could carry a small bomb payload.
The MAVAG Heja ('Hawk') was a Hungarian license-built version of the
Italian Reggiane Re.2000. It was armed with two Italian or Hungarian
12.7mm machine guns and saw action against the Red Army until the end
of World War Two.
The earliest armoured fighting vehicle developed in Japan, the
Type 92 was intended to support cavalry forces and was fully-tracked
in order to handle the poor quality roads on the Asian mainland.
It was only ever deployed in China and Manchuria.
The earliest armoured fighting vehicle developed in Japan, the
Type 92 was intended to support cavalry forces and was fully-tracked
in order to handle the poor quality roads on the Asian mainland.
It was only ever deployed in China and Manchuria. This variant has a
13.2mm hull-mounted MG with an anti-aircraft sight.
Designed in the early 1930s, the Type 94 Te-Ke was the
first mass-produced Japanese tankette. It was armed with
the powerful but slow and unreliable Type 92 7.7mm machine
gun, and saw combat throughout East Asia up to the end of World War Two.
This vehicle was designed to patrol railway lines in Manchuria,
and has a dual-drive system that allows it to run on different gauges
of railway, as well as use its own tracked drive. It has no fixed weapons,
but the commander can fire an LMG from a port on the turret. It can carry up
to five passengers. It saw action in China and Burma.
The Type 97 was meant to replace the Type 94 Te-Ke tankette
but often ended up serving alongside it. Since its intended
37mm main gun was in short supply, this variant was armed with
a powerful but slow and unreliable Type 92 7.7mm machine gun
instead. Both variants were used throughout East Asia and the South Pacific.
The Type 97 was meant to replace the Type 94 Te-Ke tankette,
but often ended up serving alongside it. The 37mm gun of this variant
was an unusually powerful weapon for a tankette. Both variants were
used throughout East Asia and the South Pacific.
The Type 95 Ha-Go was the most common Japanese tank during
World War Two. It was designed to be a fast and only lightly
armoured infantry support tank. One of its most distinctive
characteristics was the fact that the turret machine gun
was placed in a five-o'clock position.
Designed in the 1920s, the Type 89 I-Go (or Chi-Ro) was a medium infantry
support tank. The 57mm main gun was effective against infantry
and gun emplacements, but lacked armour-piercing power until
the later stages of World War Two. One of the two 6.5mm machine
guns was placed in the back of the turret.
Based on the chassis of the Type 89 I-Go medium tank, the Type 91
Soko Sagyo Ki was a multi-purpose engineering vehicle. This variant is
equipped with two flame throwers and a machine gun.
The Type 97 Chi-Ha had the highest production numbers of all
Japanese medium tanks in World War Two. Like most Japanese
tanks, it was designed for an infantry support role. The
low-velocity 57mm main gun, however, was ineffective against
most Allied tanks that it encountered.
The Type 97 Chi-Ha had the highest production numbers of all
Japanese medium tanks in World War Two. Like most Japanese
tanks, it was designed for an infantry support role. This
represents the later variant where the low-velocity 57mm main gun
has been replaced by a more powerful 47mm gun.
This is a British Stuart I Light Tank, captured and redeployed in
Japanese service.
Designed as a tank destroyer and self-propelled artillery vehicle,
the Ho-Ni was intended to take on the M4 Sherman. It combined a Type
97 chassis with a 75mm Type 90 gun mounted on the turret ring, protected
from three sides by armour plate. It was deployed in China and on Luzon in
the Philippines.
Originally based on the German Grille series of self-propelled guns,
the Ho-Ro was meant to provide the army with mechanized heavy artillery.
Only a few were ever produced, and were rushed into service in late 1944
to defend the Philippines and Okinawa.
The Type 91, or Sumida M.2593, was an armoured car designed
to be driven on railroad tracks, but it could also traverse
roads. It served from 1933 until the end of World War Two.
The Type 93 was an armoured car designed to be driven on
railroad tracks, but it could also traverse roads. Armed
with up to five machine guns and produced in limited numbers,
it served from 1933 until the end of World War Two.
The Ho-Ki was developed in 1941 to provide an armoured troop carrier
and gun tractor. The driver's cab is unusual in that it does not extend
across to the starboard side of the vehicle. 13 passengers can be transported
in the rear crew compartment. It only saw action in the Philippines in the
final months of the war.
Adopted in 1941, this was the first purpose-built anti-tank gun in the
Japanese arsenal, and had pneumatic tires so that it could be towed by a
vehicle into combat. It was quite effective against the light tanks fielded by
Nationalist Chinese and Allied forces in East Asia.
Introduced in 1936, this Japanese anti-tank gun was
designed to be operated from a squatting or prone
position. It was not powerful enough to penetrate
the front armour of most Allied tanks in the Pacific
theatre.
Introduced in 1922, this small-calibre artillery gun
was designed to be directly deployed by infantry squads,
mounting it on a portable steel tripod. It could also fire
AP shells, but because of the low velocity of the gun they
were not very effective. Also called the Year-11 gun, as it
was adopted in Showa 11.
From 1932, every Japanese infantry battalion was equipped
with two of these low-profile artillery guns. They were
capable of both direct and indirect fire support. From 1944
onward they were supplied with some HEAT in addition to HE ammunition.
This Japanese mountain gun was already used during
the Great War and remained in service until the end
of World War Two. It was supplied with HE, AP, smoke
and, from 1944, HEAT ammunition. Also called the Year 41
mountain gun.
Introduced in 1934, this Japanese mountain gun was
supposed to replace the Type 41 but often ended up
serving alongside it. It was more reliable and accurate
than its predecessor. Just like the Type 41, it could
fire a variety of shells, including HEAT rounds from
Originally purchased from Krupp after the Russo-Japanese
War, the Type 38 remained the standard field gun of the
Imperial Japanese Army until the end of World War Two.
Introduced in 1932, the Type 90 was meant to replace
the obsolete Type 38 75mm Field Gun, but its production
numbers remained too low even until the end of World War
Two. Because of its relatively high muzzle velocity, its
AP rounds were a serious threat to all Allied tanks.
Based on the French Canon de 105 mle 1913 Schneider,
this howitzer was deployed by the Imperial Japanese
Army from the invasion of Manchuria in 1931 until the
end of World War Two.
Introduced in 1934, the Type 92 10cm Cannon was a rare and
cumbersome but very successful long-range artillery gun.
Apart from its 16 kg HE shells, it could also fire AP and
smoke rounds.
This gun was originally produced in Japan in 1905 and was based on a Krupp
design. Although obsolete it was used in small numbers throughout
the 1930s and 1940s up to the end of the war.
Originally mounted on battleships and cruisers, many of these Vickers-
designed guns were later converted to static coastal defense guns on the
Pacific islands.
Originally purchased by Krupp after the Russo-Japanese
War, about 220 of these heavy howitzers were produced for
the Imperial Japanese Army. In the 1930s it was outranged
by other, superior artillery guns. Because of this, the Type
38 howitzer was removed from the frontlines in 1942.
Introduced during the Great War, the Type 4 was supposed
to replace the outdated Type 38 15cm howitzer, but ended
up serving alongside it. It was deployed until the end of
World War Two.
Originally intended to replace all outdated 15cm howitzers
in 1937, the Type 96 was used by the Imperial Japanese Army
in addition to older models during the Second Sino-Japanese
War and World War Two.
Adopted in 1933, the Type 93 combines two heavy machine guns
mounted coaxially on a tripod. It's normally fielded as part of
an anti-aircraft company.
One of the most common light anti-aircraft guns used by the Japanese
military, the Type 98 machine cannon was based on the 13.2mm Hotchkiss
machine gun, but fires 20mm AP or HE ammo.
The Type 96 Machine Cannon was the standard anti-aircraft gun on
Japanese naval vessels. Later in the war, large numbers were moved
on to land and installed as static defense guns.
The Type 96 Machine Cannon was the standard anti-aircraft gun on
Japanese naval vessels. Later in the war, large numbers were moved
on to land and installed as static defense guns. This variant has two
25mm guns mounted together for more firepower.
The Type 96 Machine Cannon was the standard anti-aircraft gun on
Japanese naval vessels. Later in the war, large numbers were moved
on to land and installed as static defense guns. This variant has three
25mm guns mounted together for maximum firepower.
Introduced in 1928, this was the standard Japanese
anti-aircraft gun until the end of World War Two.
Because of its excellent accuracy and velocity, it was
sometimes used in an anti-tank role.
Designed as a dual-purpose anti-aircraft and coastal defense weapon,
the Type 10 was originally intended for use on naval vessels, but near
the end of the war large numbers were being installed as static defense
guns on Pacific islands.
Introduced in 1934 and praised for its performance,
the Isuzu Type 94 truck quickly became the standard
truck of the Japanese military before and during World
War Two.
First produced in 1936, the Kurogane Type 95 Scout Car
was a fast and versatile Japanese reconnaisance vehicle.
It was one of the world's first four-wheel drive
passenger vehicles. Its nickname 'Yonki' means
'all-wheel drive' in Japanese.
This late-model Type 97 Chi-Ha has been partially buried and
used as a static fortification.
The Mitsubishi A6M 'Zero' was a carrier-based aircraft that entered
service in 1940 and served throughout the war.
The Kawasaki Ki-32 was a light bomber in Japanese service mainly during
the Second Sino-Japanese War.
The Kingdom of Hungary imported several hundred L3/35 tankettes
from Italy before World War Two. A significant number of them were
deployed in Yugoslavia and on the Eastern Front in 1941. The
Hungarian variant was refitted with a more reliable 8mm machine gun.
The Toldi light tank entered Hungarian service in 1940 and was first
deployed in Yugoslavia. It was a fast tank equipped with a commander
vision cupola, but its first two variants were only armed with a
Solothurn anti-tank rifle and an 8mm machine gun. It stood no chance
against advanced Soviet tanks such as the T-34.
This improved variant of the Toldi light tank was introduced in 1942.
Its main gun was upgraded to a calibre of 40mm and its armour was
reinforced.
Introduced in 1944, the Toldi III received another armour upgrade
compared to the IIa variant. Only very few Toldi III tanks were
produced before the end of World War Two.
Named after the legendary son of Attila the Hun, the Csaba remained
the standard armoured car of the Royal Hungarian Army throughout the
war despite its low production numbers. It was armed with a Solothurn
anti-tank rifle and an 8mm machine gun.
The 36M was the Hungarian designation for the German PaK 36
anti-tank gun.
The 40M anti-tank gun was a German PaK 36 rebarrelled to fit a
Skoda 40mm A17, capable of using the same ammunition as the 40mm Bofors
anti-aircraft gun. Throughout the war, it remained one of the most common
Hungarian anti-tank guns.
This is a Belgian 47mm Model 1931 anti-tank gun with a Hungarian
designation. Several hundred of these guns were captured by the Germans
in Belgium and some of them were given to the Royal Hungarian Army in
This Austrian field gun was already an outdated design at the
beginning of the Great War, but some countries - including
Hungary - kept using it until the end of World War Two.
This Austrian field howitzer from the Great War remained in
service until the end of World War Two in Hungary and several
other European countries.
This was the Hungarian designation for the German 10.5cm leFH 18
artillery gun, which was exported to Hungary before the beginning
of World War Two.
This heavy howitzer was used by Austria-Hungary during the Great War.
In Hungary and some other countries upgraded versions of it remained in
service until the end of World War Two.
The 29M 8cm was a heavy anti-aircraft gun purchased by Hungary
from the Swedish weapon manufacturer Bofors. It was also used as
a deadly anti-tank weapon.
First produced in 1938, the 38M Botond was a popular all-terrain
truck used by the Royal Hungarian Army in World War Two.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world. This model has a
short-barreled 37mm main gun and is deployed in Belgian service.
Designed in the 1930s, the AMC 35, or Automitrailleuse de
Combat Renault modele 1935, was a French cavalry tank with
limited production numbers. Rejected by the French military
for doctrinal reasons, it was exported in very small numbers
for the Belgian armoured forces.
The T15 was a variant of the Vickers Light Tank Mark III,
which entered service in 1935 intended to replace the FT
as a light tank. However, its armament was only a single
machine gun.
The T15 was a variant of the Vickers Light Tank Mark III,
which entered service in 1935 intended to replace the FT
as a light tank. A conversion to add an AA machine gun
mount on the hatches of T15s was interrupted by the German invasion.
The T15 was a variant of the Vickers Light Tank Mark III,
which entered service in 1935. This is the LCT variant,
with a highly effective 40mm Vickers QF cannon. Only 10
were imported and saw service alongside normal T15s.
The T13 B1 was a modified Vickers artillery tractor carrying
a 47mm Model 1931 AT gun. It made up a large portion of Belgium's
armoured forces in 1940.
The T13 B3 was a modified Vickers artillery tractor carrying
a 47mm Model 1931 AT gun. The B3 variant had a turret and modified
the chassis to make it more suitable for combat.
The Berliet VUDB was a French 4x4 APC which went into production
in 1929. They were not used widely by the French military with
most sent to Africa. But some were exported to Belgium, converted
later into recon vehicles. They were still in service by 1940.
This design of truck was widespread during the 1930s and 1940s,
produced by a number of different manufacturers around the world.
The 47mm Model 1931 was the primary anti-tank gun of the Belgian military in 1940
with over 750 equipping various divisions in the army. Captured examples were
later put in service with the Hungarian army.
In the late 1930s, the Soviet Union supplied China with 88 T-26 tanks,
all of which were equipped with radios. A small number were sent with the
200th Division to Burma, where they were all lost in action. The remainder
saw action in China through the rest of the war.
Universal Carriers were supplied to China through the lend-lease
programme. This variant has a Bren machine gun mounted in the bow.
Thousands of these German-built trucks were imported into China
in the 1930s, but a lack of spare parts meant that by the time war
broke out, many were in disrepair.
Thousands of Lend-Lease 2.5-Ton Trucks were built in America and sent to China
via the Burma road.
Hundreds of Willys MB 'Jeep' were supplied to China via the Burma
Road.
A large number of these German-built guns were sold to China in the
1930s, and mainly used by the expeditionary forces in Burma.
In the 1930s, Chinese arsenals produced a few dozen guns based on
a late-19th century German design developed by Krupp.
In 1929 the Chinese government purchased 120 20mm AA guns
from the Swiss firm Oerlikon. These were often pressed into
an anti-tank role as few 37mm AT Guns were available.
Infantry are still the backbone of armed forces around the world.
Although they are not as fast as armoured fighting vehicles, they
can hold positions well, and they are often armed with small anti-tank
weapons, or light or medium machine guns.
The submachine gun, a small-calibre handheld automatic carbine,
was initially developed during the Great War for close combat.
It excels at close-range combat, especially in urban environments.
Specially trained to be dropped behind enemy lines and operate
independently, paratroopers are among the most elite assault troops
deployed in the war.
Although cavalry may seem to be outdated, they are armed with
modern rifles, and horses can move much faster than people on foot.
They are also often more reliable than vehicles and require less fuel.
Mortars are simple, portable guns that can fire an HE round on a
ballistic trajectory, giving infantry some high-explosive support.
Mortars are simple, portable guns that can fire an HE round on a
ballistic trajectory, giving infantry some high-explosive support.
This is a medium-sized mortar operated by a crew of three.
Mortars are simple, portable guns that can fire an HE round on a
ballistic trajectory, giving infantry some high-explosive support.
This is a larger-sized mortar operated by a crew of four.
Anti-Tank Rifles are effective against lightly armoured vehicles,
and the two-man team that operates one can be easily concealed
for an ambush.
Heavy Machine Guns, usually distinguished by their size and the use
of a tripod mount, gained supremacy during the Great War, and are
still highly effective against infantry and unarmoured vehicles.
First used on the Western Front during the Great War, portable flamethrowers
are used by virtually every nation's armed forces. They are effective
against infantry in fortified positions and against armoured vehicles.
Combat engineers are specialists in removing and constructing
fortifications. They are also skilled assault troops.
Nikuhaku (Human Bullet) teams, formally known as Tokkotai (Special Attack Teams),
are armed with anti-tank explosives on the end
of a bamboo pole. They must detonate the charge manually and most
do not survive their suicidal attack. If they can, they will drop the armed
explosive into an open hatch, killing the tank crew instantly.
The motorcycle was an experimental technology during the Great War, but in the
Second World War they are widely used for scouting and communication
as well as light assault vehicles. These have a light machine gun mounted on
the sidecar.
Taczanka is a type of light horse carriage, whose leaf-spring suspension allowed its crews
to mount a machine gun and use it effectively in support of cavalry offensives. First deployed
by the Ukrainian anarchists, it was soon adopted by all sides of the Russian Civil War and
the Soviet-Polish War. In 1939, Polish cavalry forces continued to field many taczankas.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world. This model has a
short-barreled 37mm main gun.
First developed during the Great War, the Renault FT was the world's
first modern tank. By the outbreak of the Second World War several
thousand were still in use throughout the world. This model is armed
only with a turret-mounted machine gun.
Designed in the 1930s by the Swedish arms manufacturer
AB Bofors, this anti-aircraft gun was widely used by the
British, Americans, and their allies throughout World War 2.
This design of truck was widespread during the 1930s and 1940s,
and was produced by a number of different manufacturers around the world.
Destroyers are light, fast vessels designed for patrol or protection duties.
They excel at anti-submarine warfare, but are also used as naval artillery support.
Cruisers were an attempt to balance speed, armour, and firepower.
They are versatile warships that can operate alone or as part of a larger
battlegroup.
Battleships were among the largest and most heavily-armed warships in
the Second World War. They aimed to dominate naval combat, but proved
vulnerable to coordinated air attacks as aircraft carriers became more
widely used.
While the 1920s saw a wave of mechanization among the modern armies
of the world, throughout the Second World War horsepower is still used
to transport materials and tow guns. Horses are often more reliable
than vehicles, and require less fuel, just grasses and the
occasional apple.
While the 1920s saw a wave of mechanization among the modern armies
of the world, throughout the Second World War horsepower is still used
to transport materials and tow guns. Horses are often more reliable
than vehicles, and require less fuel, just grasses and the
occasional apple.
The C2P artillery tractor was developed in Poland to tow
the Bofors 40mm anti-aircraft gun, but they were sometimes also
used to move heavier guns. More than 300 were delivered
by the start of the war in 1939.
Many C2P artillery tractors were captured by the German forces during their
1939 invasion of Poland. They were designated Artillerie-Schlepper C2P(p),
and were redeployed in subsequent invasions.
The C4P artillery tractor was built upon the chassis of a Fiat 621 truck,
and shared most parts except for the rear tracked drive. This variant was designed
to tow artillery guns and for transporting ammo and supplies.
The C4P artillery tractor was built upon the chassis of a Fiat 621 truck,
and shared most parts except for the rear tracked drive. This variant was designed
to tow heavier guns such as the 120mm Armata field gun.
C7P was the heaviest Polish artillery tractor design, and it was
the only Polish vehicle capable of towing 220mm super-heavy mortars. While
over 300 were ordered, only half of that number was actually delivered
by the start of the war in 1939.
Many C7P artillery tractors were captured by the German forces during their
1939 invasion of Poland. They were designated Artillerie-Schlepper C7P(p),
and were redeployed in the subsequent invasions.
A few C7P artillery tractors were captured by Soviet forces during
their invasion of eastern Poland and were redeployed into service
during the early part of the war.
Unic P107 was a French half-track prime mover, initially designed by Citroen
but ultimately produced by Unic after Citroen went bankrupt and was re-acquired
by Michelin. By June 1940, over 3000 were produced.
Unic P107 was a French half-track prime mover, initially designed by Citroen
but ultimately produced by Unic after Citroen went bankrupt and was re-acquired
by Michelin. By June 1940, over 3000 were produced. Most were captured by the
Germans in good condition, and were redeployed as Zugkraftwagen 37 U304(f).
The Laffly S15T was designed to tow artillery pieces such as the
75mm field gun and the 105mm howitzer. Only around 400 were produced
in total.
The Laffly S15T was designed to tow artillery pieces such as the
75mm field gun and the 105mm howitzer. Some units were exported to
Romania alongside the Renault R35 tanks.
The Renault UE 'Chenillette' was an armoured tractor, designed to
tow guns in order to keep up with fully mechanized military units
Thousands were produced in 1930s.
Thousands of Renault UE tractors were captured during the Battle of France
in good condition. The majority continued to serve as gun tractors under the
designation Infanterie Schlepper UE 630(f).
The Renault UE 'Chenillette' was an armoured tractor, designed to
tow guns in order to keep up with fully mechanized military units.
Some of these gun tractors were exported to the Republic of China,
and they were used during the Second Sino-Japanese War.
The Renault UE 'Chenillette' was an armoured tractor, designed to
tow guns in order to keep up with fully mechanized military units.
126 were produced under license in Romania under this designation,
and 50 more were delivered by Germany after the Fall of France.
The Renault UE 'Chenillette' was an armoured tractor, designed to
tow guns in order to keep up with fully mechanized military units.
It was not just deployed in France but also in its overseas colonies
and some of these gun tractors were captured by Thailand after the
Franco-Thai War.
The Sonderkraftfahrzeug 2 was a half-track motorcycle, initially designed to tow
light guns for airborne troops. While first developed in 1939, it was not deployed
until Operation Barbarossa. Nearly 9000 were produced in total, with the majority
deployed on the Eastern Front.
The Sonderkraftfahrzeug 7 was a half-tracked vehicle capable of towing the majority
of the German artillery pieces, including the 88mm anti-aircraft gun. It was also
frequently used as a recovery vehicle for damaged tanks. Around 10,000 were produced
by the end of the war.
The Sonderkraftfahrzeug 7 was a half-tracked vehicle capable of towing the majority
of the German artillery pieces, including the 88mm anti-aircraft gun. It was also
frequently used as a recovery vehicle for damaged tanks. By 1939, 76 were exported to Hungary,
where they were used under this designation.
This was a licensed Italian copy of the German Sonderkraftfahrzeug 7 half-track
gun tractor. It wasn't deployed until near the end of the Italian participation
in the war, and most of these vehicles were ultimately seized and redeployed after
the German occupation.
Raupenschlepper Ost was developed in 1942 on the basis of tracked Soviet artillery
tractors, in response to the inadequate performance of their German equivalents on
the Eastern Front. In spite of its name, it was soon deployed on the Western Front
as well, and around 23,000 were produced in total.
Raupenschlepper Ost was developed in 1942 on the basis of tracked Soviet artillery
tractors, in response to the inadequate performance of their German equivalents on
the Eastern Front. Around 23,000 were produced in total, and 100 were exported to Romania in 1943.
The Sonderkraftfahrzeug 10 was a half-tracked vehicle designed for towing
guns and trailers that saw widespread use throughout the war. Over 14,000
were built throughout the war, including several thousand specialized vehicles
based on the same basic hull.
This was a French gun tractor, captured and redeployed in German service.
Only a minority were used as tractors for long, with the majority eventually
converted into some form of an assault gun or a different utility vehicle.
Krupp Protze was extensively produced before the war as a tractor
for light anti-tank guns and anti-aircraft guns. Around 7000 were
produced between 1934 and 1941, when their production ceased because the
weapons they were intended to tow were no longer in demand.
Krupp Protze was extensively produced in Germany before the war as a tractor
for light anti-tank guns and anti-aircraft guns. Up to 150 were exported to
Hungary in 1937 and 1938.
This was one of the earliest Italian gun tractors, assigned to the heaviest artillery
batteries. Its production began in 1932, and by 1940 the remaining vehicles were showing
their age.
This gun tractor had a slow road speed due to its weak engine, but it
had good off-road mobility due to its small size and a full-wheel drive.
Around 200 were used by the Italian military.
This full-wheel drive vehicle built upon SPA TL 37 to provide a lighter,
more mobile alternative to Breda gun tractors. It did not enter service until 1942.
After the Italian armistice, SPA TM 40 gun tractor was one of the numerous Italian
vehicles captured by the occupying German troops. It was redeployed as Radschlepper
110 PS SPA(i), and 115 more were produced under occupation throughout 1944.
This was a modernized version of Breda TP 32, with numerous improvements
intended to improve its reliability. While it was designed in 1940, it
did not enter service until 1942.
This Pavesi gun tractor was designed in 1925, but was modernized
in 1937. It could tow remarkably heavy guns for its small size,
but at the expense of very limited mobility.
This Italian Pavesi gun tractor was first designed in 1925, and the
modernized version was still in service with the Italian forces in 1940s.
Some of the original models were also exported to Hungary.
M1 Heavy Tractor was a general designation for a range of
high-capacity civilian tractors adopted by the US military
to tow its heaviest artillery guns. By the end of the war,
they were phased out in favour of specialized models.
By the end of 1941, the Soviet Union lost the majority of its
prewar military vehicle stock, and heavy artillery tractors
Komintern and Voroshilovets were no exception. Altogether, over
