1000 of these American tractors were leased to help make up for this loss.
The M4 High Speed Tractor was an artillery tractor that used the
tracks from a Sherman tank. It normally towed either the 90mm anti-
aircraft gun or the 155mm howitzer. It was faster than its foreign
equivalents, and was also equipped with an M2 Browning machine gun
for self-defense. Nearly 6000 were produced between 1943 and 1945.
The M5 High Speed Tractor was an artillery tractor designed and
produced in parallel to the M4. Unlike the M4, it used the tracks
and the suspension from the Stuart tank, yet it was similar in all
other respects. It entered production two months after the M4 HST,
and around 5,200 were produced by the end of the war.
The M5 High Speed Tractor was an artillery tractor designed and
produced in parallel to the M4. Unlike the M4, it used the tracks
and the suspension from the Stuart tank, yet it was similar in all
other respects. It entered production in May 1943, and 200 units
were delivered to the Red Army in 1944.
Contrary to its name, the M6 High Speed Tractor was a lot slower
than the M4 and M5 HST, but this was more than offset by its ability
to tow the super-heavy guns like the 240mm 'Black Dragon' howitzer.
Around 1000 were produced in 1944 and 1945, and they were deployed
exclusively on the European theater.
The M33 Prime Mover was an artillery tractor converted from the M3 Lee
chassis, designed to tow the heaviest guns in the US service. 109 vehicles
were converted in 1943-1944, and they were deployed in Italy and in Normandy.
The M34 Prime Mover was an artillery tractor converted from M4A1
Sherman chassis. 24 such conversions were performed in 1944.
The M35 Prime Mover was an artillery tractor converted from M10
Wolverine tank destroyer in order to tow the heaviest artillery
pieces in the US Army. Over 200 conversions were performed before
the introduction of the M6 HST.
The Mack Heavy Artillery Tractor was a 6-wheeled, all-wheel drive
truck capable of towing the heaviest guns in the US Army. Around 2000
were produced starting from June 1943.
Originally known as Vickers Light Dragon, this was a tankette-scale
light tractor design. It was rejected by the British military, but
was adopted by the Belgian army.
Originally known as Vickers Light Dragon, this was a tankette-scale
light tractor design. It was rejected by the British military, but
was adopted by the Belgian army to tow light artillery pieces for its
mobile 'cavalry' regiments.
Originally known as Vickers Light Dragon, this was a tankette-scale
light tractor design. It was rejected by the British military, but
was adopted by the Belgian army. The larger and more capable infantry
version was also reused by the German army as Artillerie-Schlepper Vickers-Armstrong 601(b).
Over 25,000 Loyd Carriers were produced from 1939 to 1944. During the early
war, it was only used as an APC for small teams, but it was inferior to the
Universal Carrier in that role. By the time of the Normandy landings, it was
primarily used to tow 6-pdr guns in its Tracked Towing (TT) configuration.
The Canadian Military Pattern Field Artillery Tractor was a wheeled
4x4 truck designed to tow 25-pdr or 18-pdr guns.
The Morris Commercial C8 Field Artillery Tractor was a wheeled
4x4 truck designed to tow 25-pdr or 18-pdr guns. Around 10,000
were produced between 1940 and 1945.
Type 92 I-Ke was the oldest Japanese artillery tractor
in service at the time of the war, with the first series
produced from 1931 and a diesel version entering production
in 1936. Altogether, over 400 were produced.
This was the most widely available Japanese artillery tractor,
with over 1,600 models produced beginning from 1932. It had a
low road speed due to an old and low-powered engine, and its
simplified design resulted in a comparatively high ground pressure.
Designed in 1934, Type 94 Yo-Ke was the smallest and the most mobile
Japanese gun tractor. However, it was a flawed design, and only 133
were produced before work began on a new design. Like its successor
Type 98 Shi-Ke, it was used to tow the Type 91 howitzer.
This was the largest and the most powerful Japanese artillery tractor.
While it could tow any gun or vehicle in Japanese service, it was also
the slowest wartime vehicle of its class. 373 were produced.
Type 98 Shi-Ke was one of the faster and more modern Japanese
gun tractors. It entered production in 1938 and was primarily
used to tow the Type 91 howitzer. Nearly 800 were produced.
Type 98 Ro-Ke was one of the faster and more modern Japanese
gun tractors. It entered production in 1938 and was primarily
used to tow the Type 91 howitzer. Nearly 800 were produced.
Landsverk L-131 was a Swedish gun tractor designed in 1934.
The following year, 20 were ordered by Thailand, and they were
all in service during the Franco-Thai War.
STZ-3 was designed at the Stalingrad Tractor Factory, and was the first
Soviet agricultural tractor which had no basis on foreign designs. Almost
200,000 models were produced between 1937 and 1952, nearly all of them after
the war. During the war, it was regularly pressed into military service whenever
the dedicated artillery tractors were unavailable.
STZ-5 was the upgraded artillery tractor version of the civilian STZ-3.
Around 3500 were produced at Stalingrad Tractor Factory before June 1941, and
nearly 10,000 were completed before the Battle of Stalingrad, making it the
most numerous Soviet artillery tractor of the war. Its nickname means 'Follower of Stalin'.
Large numbers of the STZ-5 were captured by the Germans during the
early part of the war, who mistranslated its name and placed it into
service under an incorrect designation.
Komintern (portmanteau of Communist International) was a powerful
gun tractor capable of towing virtually any artillery piece in Soviet
service, including the super-heavy 203mm howitzer. It was replaced in
production by the even heavier Voroshilovets in 1940, yet there were
still 1500 in service in June 1941, and around 500 were left by the end
of the war.
Komintern (portmanteau of Communist International) was a powerful
gun tractor capable of towing virtually any artillery piece in Soviet
service, including the super-heavy 203mm howitzer. Hundreds were lost
by the end of 1941, with some redeployed in German service under the designation
Artillerie-Schlepper 604(r).
Komsomolets ('Communist Youth') was an armoured artillery tractor, developed in the mid-1930s
alongside amphibitious tankettes. While it was only designed to tow
light anti-tank guns and short 76mm guns, its use had dramatically improved
their response time. Nearly 8000 were produced between 1937 and late 1941, when its production lines
were devoted to what would become the T-60.
T-20 Komsomolets was an armoured artillery tractor, developed in the mid-1930s
alongside the Soviet amphibitious tankettes, and armed with a single machine gun.
Nearly 8000 were made before production ended in late 1941, and some were lost to
the Finnish forces during the Winter War and the Continuation War.
T-20 Komsomolets was an armoured artillery tractor, developed in the mid-1930s
alongside the Soviet amphibitious tankettes, and armed with a single machine gun.
Nearly 8000 were made before production ended in late 1941. Many units ended up
captured by the Germans during the early war, and were redeployed as Artillerie-Schlepper 630(r).
T-20 Komsomolets was an armoured artillery tractor, developed in the mid-1930s
alongside the Soviet amphibitious tankettes, and armed with a single machine gun.
Nearly 8000 were made before production ended in late 1941. Some 36 are known to
have been captured and reused by the Romanian military.
This was a gun tractor version of the T-26 tank. While the project
began in the early 1930s, it was soon outproduced by Komsomolets and
only 217 tanks were converted in total, with the vast majority lost by 1942.
This was a gun tractor version of the T-26 tank. Some
were deployed during the Winter War, and around a dozen
were known to have been captured and redeployed by the Finnish army.
Many T-60 light tanks ended up captured by the Germans,
and while some were redeployed as-is, the majority were
soon converted to armoured artillery tractors and munition carriers.
Some T-70 light tanks ended up captured by the Germans,
and some were known to have been converted to armoured
artillery tractors.
Voroshilovets, meaning 'follower of Voroshilov', was the most powerful
wartime Soviet gun tractor. It could tow any artillery piece, and at a
higher speed than its predecessor. As with the KV tanks, its
name referred to the People's Commissar of Defense Kliment Voroshilov.
1100 were produced before its Kharkov factory had to be abandoned in August
Some Voroshilovets gun tractors were captured and
redeployed in German service as Artillerie-Schlepper 607(r).
This is a simulated enemy riflemen squad, armed with light weapons, grenades, possibly
a LMG or MMG, and possibly close combat anti-tank weapons as well.
This is a target armoured car, meant to simulate an enemy unit.
The training team can simulate gun or MG attacks from it at you or your allies.
This is a target anti-tank gun, meant to simulate an enemy unit.
The training team can simulate gun attacks from it at you or your allies.
This is a target artillery gun, meant to simulate an enemy unit.
The training team can simulate gun attacks from it at you or your allies.
This is a target Anti-Tank Rifle team, meant to simulate an enemy unit.
The training team can simulate attacks from it at you or your allies.
A steel and wood target, meant to represent an enemy medium tank.
The training team can simulate gun or MG attacks from it at you or your allies.
